It was Alisaunders, þe gret lording, When he fau?t wiþ Poreus þe king, Þat hard him gan aseyle. 93 A gode swerd he hadde, wiþ-outen faile, Þat was Ectors in Troye batayle, In gest as so men fint. Ar he þat swerd dede forgon, Of Grece he slou? þer mani on, Þat died þurch þat dint. Hose & gambisoun so gode kni?t schold, A targe listed wiþ gold About his swere he hint. Nas neuer wepen þat euer was make[d] Þat o schel mi?t þerof take, Na more þan of þe flint. 94 Or king Triamours elders it lau?t, King Darri sum time it au?t: Þat Gij was vnder pi?t. Ich man axe oþer bigan Whennes & who was þat man Þat wiþ þe geaunt durst fi?t. King Triamour seyd wiþ wordes fre, ‘Sir Soudan, herken now to me, Astow art hendy kni?t. To þi court icham now come To defende me of þat ich gome Þat is so stern of si?t. 95 Þis litel kni?t þat stont me by Schal fende me of þat felonie, & make me quite & skere.’ ‘Be stille,’ seyd þe Soudan þo, ‘Þat batail schal wel sone be go, Also brouke y mi swere.’ He dede clepe Amorant so grim, & Gij stode & loked on him, Hou foule he was of chere. ‘It is,’ seyd Gij, ‘no mannes sone: It is a deuel fram helle is come. What wonder doþ he here? 96 Who mi?t his dintes dreye, Þat he no schuld dye an heye? So strong he is of dede.’ Þan speken þai alle of þe batayle: Where it schuld be, wiþ-outen fayle, Þai token hem to rede. Þan loked þai it schuld be In a launde vnder þe cite: Þider þai gun hem lede. Wiþ a riuer it ern al about: Þer-in schuld fi?t þo kni?tes stout. Þai mi?t fle for no nede. 97 Ouer þe water þai went in a bot, On hors þai lopen fot hot, Þo kni?tes egre of mode. Þai priked þe stedes þat þai on sete, & smiten togider wiþ dentes grete, & ferd as þai wer wode, Til her schaftes in þat tide Gun to schiuer bi ich a side About hem þer þai stode. Þan þai drou? her swerdes grounde, & hewe togider wiþ grimli wounde, Til þai spradde al ablode. 98 Sir Amoraunt drou? his gode brond, Þat wele carf al þat it fond, When he hadde lorn his launce: Þat neuer armour mi?t wiþstond Þat was made of smitþes hond In heþenesse no in Fraunce. It was sir Ercules þe strong, Þat mani he slou? þer-wiþ wiþ wrong In batayle & in destaunce. Þer was neuer man þat it bere Ouer-comen in batayle no in were, Bot it were þurch meschaunce. 99 It was baþed in þe flom of helle: A goddes ?af it him to wille, He schuld þe better spede. Who þat bar þat swerd of mi?t, Was neuer man ouercomen in fi?t, Bot it were þurch vnlede. Þer worþ sir Gij to deþ y-brou?t, Bot ?if god haue of him þou?t, His best help at nede. Togider þai wer ?ern heweinde Wiþ her brondes wele kerueinde, And maden her sides blede. 100 Sir Amoraunt was agreued in hert, & smot to Gij a dint ful smert Wiþ alle þe mi?t he gan welde, & hitt him on þe helme so bri?t, Þat alle þe stones of michel mi?t Fley?e doun in þe feld. Al of þe helme þe swerd out stint, & forþ ri?t wiþ þat selue dint Oþer half fot of þe scheld, Þat neuer was atamed ar þan For kni?t no for no noþer man, No were he neuer so beld. 101 Þe sadel bowe he clef atvo, Þe stedes nek he dede also, Wiþ his grimli brond. Wiþ-outen wem or ani wounde Wele half a fot in-to þe grounde Þe scharp swerd it wond. Sir Gij to grounde fallen is, He stirt vp anon, y-wis, & loked, & gan wiþ-stond. Anon ri?t in þat ich stede To god almi?ten he bad his bede, & held vp boþe his hond. 102 Sir Gij anon vp stirt As man þat was agremed in hert, Nou?t wel long he lay. ‘Lord,’ seyd Gij, ‘god al-mi?t, Þat made þe þerkenes to þe ni?t, So help me to-day. Scheld me fro þis geaunt strong, Þat y no deþ of him afong, Astow art lord verray. Þat dint,’ he seyd, ‘was iuel sett. Wele schal y com out of þi dett ?if þat I libbe may.’ 103 Gij hent his swerd, þat was ful kene, & smot Amoraunt wiþ hert tene A dint þat sat ful sore, Þat a quarter of his scheld He made to fleye in þe feld Al wiþ his grimli gore. Þe stedes nek he smot atvo, Amoraunt to grounde is fallen þo: Wo was him þerfore. Þan wer on fot þo kni?tes bold: Fi?t ofot ?if þai wold. Her stedes þai han forlore. 104 Amoraunt wiþ hert ful grim Smot to Gij, & Gij to him, Wiþ strokes stern & stiue. Hard þai hewe wiþ swerdes clere, Þat helme & swerd, þat strong were, Þai gun hem al to-driue. Hard fou?ten þo champiouns, Þat boþe plates & hauberiouns Þai gun to ret & riue, & laiden on wiþ dintes gret. Aiþer of hem so oþer gan bete, Þat wo was hem oliue. 105 Sir Amoraunt was agreued strong, Þat o man stode him þo so long. To Gij a strok he rau?t, & hit him on þe helme so bri?t, Þat al þe floures fel doun ri?t. Wiþ a ful grimly drau?t Þe cercle of gold he carf ato, & forþ wiþ his dint also Þer bileued it nou?t: On þe scheld þe swerd doun fel, And cleue it in-to haluendel, Almost to grounde him brou?t. 106 What wiþ þe swerdes out draweing, & wiþ his hetelich out braiding, Þer fel a wonder cas: Sir Gij fel on knes to grounde, & stirt vp in þat selue stounde, & seyd, ‘lord ful of grace, Neuer dint of kni?t non No mi?t me are knele don In no stede þer y was.’ Sir Gij hent vp his swerd fot hot, Amoraunt on þe hod he smot, Þat he stumbled in þe place. 107 He hit him on þe helme an hey?e, & wiþ þat dint þe swerd it fley?e: Bi þe nasel it gan doun founde, & so it dede bi þe ventayle, & carf it ato, saunfaile, & in-to his flesche a wounde. His targe wiþ gold list He carf atvo þurch help of Crist, He cleue þat ich stounde. So heteliche þe brond out he pli?t, Þat Amoraunt anon ri?t Fel on knes to grounde. 108 So strong batayle was hem bitvene: So seyd þai þat mi?t it sene Þat seye þai neuer non swiche, Þat neuer was of wiman born Swiche to kni?tes as þai worn, Þat fou?ten togider wiþ wreche. On a day bifor þe natiuite Of seyn Ion, þe martir fre, Þat holy man is to seche, Togider fou?t þo barouns boþe, Þat in hert wer so wroþe. Of loue was þer no speche. 109 Sir Amoraunt wiþ-drou? him Wiþ loureand chere wroþ & grim, For þe blod of him was lete, Þat drink he most, oþer his liif forgon: So strong þrust ?ede him opon, So michel was his hete. ‘Fourti batayls ichaue ouercome, Ac fond y neuer er moder sone Þat me so sore gan bete. Tel me,’ he seyd, ‘what artow? Felt y neuer man ar now Þat ?af dintes so grete. 110 Tel me,’ he seyd, ‘wennes þou be; For þou art strong, so mot y the, & of michel mi?t.’ Sir Gij answerd, ‘wiþ-outen bost, Cristen icham, wele þou wost, Of Inglond born, y pli?t. King Triamour me hider brou?t For to defenden him, ?if y mou?t, Of þat michel vnri?t Þat ?e beren on him wiþ wou?, Þat Fabour neuer Sadony slou? Noiþer bi day no ni?t.’ 111 ‘O, artow Inglis?’ seyd Amorant. ‘Now wald mi lord Teruagaunt Þat þou were Gij þe strong! Mahoun ?af þat þou wer he! Bliþe wald y þan be Batail of him to fong: For he haþ destrud al our lawe, His heued wald ichaue ful fawe, Or hei?e on galwes hong; For keuer schal we neuer more Þat he haþ don ous forlore Wiþ wel michel wrong. 112 Wiþ michel wrong & michel wou? Fourti þousend of ous he slou? In Costentin on a day: He & Herhaud, his felawe, Michel han destrud our lawe, Þat euer-more mon y may. ?if he wer slain wiþ brond of stiel Þan were y wroken on hem ful wel Þat han destrud our lay.’ Sir Gij answerd, ‘whi seistow so? Haþ Gij ani þing þe misdo?’ Amoraunt seyd, ‘nay, 113 Ac it wer gret worþschip, y-wis, To alle þe folk of heþenisse, Þat y hadde so wroken mi kende. Cristen,’ he seyd, ‘listen to me. Þe weder is hot, astow may se; Y pray þe, leue frende: Leue, to drink þou lat me gon For þe lordes loue þou leuest on, Astow art gode & hende. For þrist mi hert wil to-spring, & for hete, wiþ-outen lesing, Mi liue wil fro me wende. 114 & ?if y schal be þus aqueld Þurch strong hete in þe feld It were o?ain þe skille: Unworþschipe it war to þe, It were þe gret vilete In wat lond þou com tille. Ac lete me drink a litel wi?t For þi lordes loue ful of mi?t Þat þou louest wiþ wille, & y þe hot bi mi lay, ?if þou haue ani þrest to-day, Þou shalt drink al þi fille.’ 115 Sir Gij answerd, ‘y graunt þe, & ?ete to-day þou ?eld it me Wiþ-outen ani fayle.’ & when he hadde leue of sir Gij He was ful glad, sikerli: No lenger nold he dayle. To þe riuer ful swiþe he ran, His helme of his heued he nam, & vnlaced his ventayle. When he hadde dronken alle his fille He stirt vp wiþ hert grille, & sir Gij began to asayle. 116 ‘Kni?t,’ he seyd, ‘?eld þe biliue; For þou art giled, so mot y þriue. Now ichaue a drink, Icham as fresche as ich was amorwe: Þou schalt dye wiþ michel sorwe, For-soþe, wiþouten lesing.’ Þan þai drowen her swerdes long, Þo kni?tes þat wer stern & strong, Wiþ-outen more dueling, & aiþer gan oþer þer asayle; & þer bi-gan a strong bataile Wiþ wel strong fi?ting. 117 Amoraunt was ful egre of mode, & smot to Gij as he wer wode (Ful egre he was to fi?t), Þat a quarter of his scheld He made it fleye into the feld, And of his brini bri?t: Of his scholder þe swerd glod doun, Þat boþe plates & hauberioun He carf atvo, y pli?t, Al to þe naked hide, y-wis, & nou?t of flesche atamed is Þurch grace of god almi?t. 118 Þe scharp swerd doun gan glide Fast bi sir Gyes side (His knew it com ful neye), Þat gambisoun & iambler Boþe it karf atvo y-fere: Into þerþe þe swerd it fleye Wiþ-outen wem or ani wounde Half a fot in-to þe grounde, Þat mani man it seye. & when Gij seye þat fair grace, Þat noþing wounded he was, Iesu he þanked on heye. 119 & when Gij feld him so smite He was wroþ, ?e mow wite: To Amoraunt he gan reken. He hent his brond wiþ wel gode wille, & stroke to him wiþ hert grille: His scheld he gan to-breken. So hetelich Gij him smot, Þat into þe scholder half a fot Þe gode swerd gan reken; & wiþ þat strok Gij wiþ-drou?: Weri he was forfou?ten y-nou?; To Amoraunt he gan speken. 120 ‘Sir Amoraunt,’ þan seyd Gij, ‘For godes loue now merci, ?if that þi wille be. Ichaue swiche þrist þer y stond, Y may vnneþe drawe min hond; Þerfore wel wo is me. ?eld me now þat ich dede: Y ?af þe leue to drink at nede. Astow art hende & fre, Leue, to drink þou lat me go, As it was couenaunt bitven ous tvo: For loue y pray þe.’ 121 ‘Hold þi pes,’ seyd Amoraunt, ‘For, bi mi lord sir Teruagaunt, Leue no hastow non. Ac now þat y þe soþe se, Þat þou ginnes to feynt þe, Þine heued þou schalt forgon.’ ‘Amoraunt,’ seyd Gij, ‘do ari?t: Lete me drink a litel wi?t As y dede þe anon, & togider fi?t we: Who schal be maister we schal se, Wiche of ous may oþer slon.’ 122 ‘Hold þi pays,’ seyd Amoraunt, ‘Y nil nou?t held þe couenaunt For ful þis toun of gold; For when ichaue þe sleyn now ri?t Þe Soudan, treweli, haþ me hi?t His lond ?if me he schold Euermore to haue & hold fre, & ?iue me his dou?ter bri?t o ble, Þe miriest may on mold: When ichaue þe sleyn þis day He schal ?iue me þat fair may Wiþ alle his lond to hold. 123 Ac do now wele & vnarme þe, & trewelich ?eld þou þe to me: Oliue y lat þe gon. & ?if þou wilt nou?t do bi mi red Þou schalt dye on iuel ded: Ri?t now y schal þe slon.’ ‘Nay,’ seyd Gij, ‘þat war no lawe: Ich hadde leuer to ben to-drawe Þan swiche a dede to don. Ar ich wald creaunt ?eld me Ich hadde leuer an-hanged be, & brent boþe flesche & bon.’ 124 Þan seyd Amoraunt, ‘at a word, Bi þe treuþe þou owe þi lord, Þat þou louest so dere, Tel me what þi name it be, & leue to drink ?iue y þe Þi fille of þis riuer. Þou seyd þi name is sir Youn: It is nou?t so, bi seyn Mahoun, It is a lesing, fere. ?if þi name were Youn ri?t Þou nere nou?t of so miche mi?t, No þus vnbiknowen here.’ 125 ‘Frende,’ seyd Gij, ‘y schal telle þe: Astow art hendi man & fre, Þou wray me to no wi?t. Gij of Warwike mi name it is: In Inglond y was born, y-wis. Lete me now drink wiþ ri?t.’ When Amoraunt seye, sikerly, Þat it was þe gode Gij Þat o?aines him was di?t, He loked on him wiþ michel wrake Sternliche wiþ his ey?en blake, Wiþ an vnsemli si?t. 126 ‘Sir Gij,’ he seyd, ‘welcom to me! Mahoun, mi lord, y thank þe Þat ich haue þe her-inne. Michel schame þou hast me don: Þi liif þou schalt astite forgon, Þi bodi schal atvinne, & þine heued, bi Teruagaunt, Mi leman schal haue to presaunt, Þat comly is of kinne. Hennes-forward, siker þou be, Leue no tit þe non of me, For al þis warld to winne.’ 127 ‘Allas,’ seyd Gij, ‘what schal y don? Now y no may haue drink non Mine hert brekeþ ato.’ Anon he biþou?t him þenne Ri?t to þe riuer he most renne: He turned him, & gan to go. Amoraunt wiþ swerd on hond He thou?t haue driuen Gij to schond: Wiþ sorwe he wald him slo. Gij ran to þe water ri?t: Bot on him þenke god almi?t Vp comeþ he neuer mo. 128 Þo was sir Gij in gret drede. In þe water he stode to his girdel stede, & þat þou?t him ful gode. In þe water he dept his heued anon, Ouer þe schulders he dede it gon; Þat keled wele his blod. & when Gij hadde dronken anou? Hetelich his heued vp he drou? Out of þat ich flod; & Amoraunt stode opon þe lond With a drawen swerd in hond, & smot Gij þer he stode. 129 Hetelich he smot Gyoun: Into þat water he fel adoun Wiþ þat dint vnride, Þat þe water arn him about. Sir Gij stirt vp in gret dout: For noþing he nold abide, & schoke his heued as kni?t bold. ‘In þis water icham ful cold Wombe, rigge, & side, & no leue, sir, ich hadde of þe, & þer-fore haue þo[u] miche maugre, & iuel þe mot bi-tide.’ 130 Sir Gij stirt vp, wiþouten fayl, & Amoraunt he gan to asayl: To fi?t he was ful boun. Hard togider þai gan to fi?t: Of loue was þer no speche, y pli?t, Bot heweing wiþ swerdes broun. ‘Amoraunt,’ þan seyd Gij, ‘Þou art ful fals, sikerly, & ful-filt of tresoun. No more wil y trust to þe For no bihest þou hotest me: Þou art a fals glotoun.’ 131 Hard togider þai gun fi?t: Fro þe morwe to þe ni?t Þat long somers day, So long þai fou?ten boþe þo. Wiche was þe better of hem to Noman chese no may. Bot at a strok as Amoraunt cast, Sir Gij mett wiþ him in hast, & tau?t him a sori play: Þe ri?t arme wiþ þe swerd fot hot Bi þe scholder of he it smot, To grounde it fleye oway. 132 When Amoraunt feld him to smite In his left hond wiþ michel hete Þe swerd he hent fot hot: As a lyoun þan ferd he, Þritti sautes he made & þre Wiþ his swerd, þat wel bot; Bot for þe blod þat of him ran Amoraunt strengþe slake bigan. When Gij þat soþ wot, Þat Amoraunt was faynting, Sir Gij him folwed wiþouten dueling: Þat oþer hond of he smot. 133 When Amoraunt had boþe hondes forlore A wreche he held him-self þerfore: His wit was alto-dreued. On sir Gij he lepe wiþ alle his mi?t, Þat almast he had feld him doun ri?t, & sir Gij was agreued, & stirt bisiden fot hot, & Amoraunt in þe nek he smot: His mi?t he haþ him bireued. He fel to grounde, wiþouten faile, & sir Gij vnlaced his ventayle, & he strok of his heued. 134 Ouer þe water he went in a bot, & present þer-wiþ fot hot Þe king, sir Triamour. Þe king, sir Triamour, þan Went to þat riche Soudan, & also his sone Fabour. Þan was þe Soudan swiþe wo: Quite-claim he lete hem go Wiþ wel michel honour. Into Alisaunder þai went, þat cite, & ladde wiþ hem sir Gij þe fre, Þat hadde ben her socour. 135 Þe king tok þerl Ionas þo, & clept him in his armes to, & kist him swete, ich wene, An hundred times & ?ete mo, & quite-claim he lete him go & his sones fiftene. ‘Erl Ionas,’ seyd þe king, ‘Herken now to my teling, & what ichil mene: For mi liif þou sauedest me, Half mi lond ich graunt þe Wiþ þis kni?t strong & kene. 136 Vnderstond to me, sir kni?t: Mahoun ?aue ful of mi?t Þou wost duelle wiþ me! Þridde part mi lond y ?iue þe to: Michel honour ichil þe do, A riche prince make þe. Y nil nou?t þou forsake god þine: Þou art bileueand wele afine Better may no be.’ Sir Gij answerd him ful stille, ‘Sir, of þi lond nou?t y nille, For-soþe y telle þe.’ 137 Þat erl to Ierusalem went anon, Gij of Warwike wiþ him gan gon & alle his sones on rawe. Þerl wold ?if he mi?t Wite þe name of þat kni?t, ?if he him euer-more sawe. In conseyl, ‘sir kni?t,’ þan seyd he, ‘Þat þou Youn dost clep þe, Þou no hatest nou?t so, y trowe. For Iesu loue y pray þe, Þat died on þe rode tre, Þi ri?t name be aknawe.’ 138 Sir Gij seyd, ‘þou schalt now here, Seþþen þou frainest me in þis maner: Mi name ichil þe sayn. Gij of Warwike mi name is ri?t. Astow art hende & gentil kni?t, To non þou schalt me wrayn. Batayl for þi loue y nam, & þe geaunt ouer-cam; Þerof icham ful fain.’ When þerl seye it was sir Gij He fel doun on knes him bi, & wepe wiþ boþ his ayn. 139 ‘For godes loue,’ he seyd, ‘merci! Whi artow so pouer, sir Gij, & art of so gret valour? Here ich ?iue þe in þis place Al þerldam of Durras, Cite & castel tour: Þi man ichil bicomen & be, & alle mi sones forþ wiþ me Schal com to þi socour; For þe priis of heþen lond Þou hast þurch douhtines of hond Wonne wiþ gret vigour.’ 140 ‘Erl Ionas,’ þan seyd sir Gij, ‘Mi leue frende, gramerci For þi gode wille! Þan schustow hire me al to dere To ?iue me þi lond in swiche manere; Þer-of nou?t y nille. To ?our owen cuntre wendeþ hom: God biteche y ?ou euerichon. Mi way ichil ful-fille.’ Þan went & kist him eueri man: Þerl so sore wepe bigan, Þat mi?t him no man stille. 141 Þerl to Durras went anon & his sones euerichon, Were scaped out of care. Gij þan in his way is nome: For þat þe geaunt was ouer-come, Ful bliþe þan was he þare. Into Grece þan went he, & sou?t halwen of þat cuntre, Þe best þat þer ware. Seþþe forþ in his way he ?ede Þurch-out mani vncouþe þede: To Costentyn he is y-fare. 142 When Gij in Costentin hadde be Out of þat lond þan went he, Walkand in þe strete On pilgrimage in his iurnay, His bedes bidand ni?t & day, His sinnes for to bete. In Almaine þan went he, y-wis, Þer he was sumtime holden of gret pris. He com to a four way lete Bi?onde Espire, þat riche cite: Under a croice, was maked of tre, A pilgrim he gan mete, 143 Þat wrong his honden, & wepe sore, & curssed þe time þat he was bore: ‘Allas,’ it was his song. ‘Wayleway,’ he seyd, ‘that stounde! Wickedliche icham brou?t to grounde Wiþ wel michel wrong.’ Sir Gij went to him þo: ‘Man,’ he seys, ‘whi farstow so? So god ?eue þe ioie to fong, Tel me what þi name it be, & whi þou makest þus gret pite: Meþenke þi paynes strong.’ 144 ‘Godeman,’ seyd þe pilgrim þo, ‘What hastow to frein me so? Swiche sorwe icham in sou?t, Þat, þei y told þe alle mi care, For þe mi?t y neuer þe better fare: To grounde icham so brou?t.’ ‘?is,’ seyd Gij, ‘bi þe gode rode, Conseyl y can ?iue þe gode, & tow telle me þi þou?t; For oft it falleþ vncouþe man Þat gode conseyle ?iue can. Þerfore hele it nou?t.’ 145 ‘For god,’ he seyd, ‘þou seyst ful wel. Sumtime ich was, by seyn Mi?hel, An erl of gret pouste. Þurch al cristendom, y-wis, Ich was teld a man of gret pris & of gret bounte, & now icham a wroche beggare: No wonder þei icham ful of care. Allas, wel wo is me!’ For sorwe he mi?t speke na more: He gan to wepe swiþe sare, Þat Gij hadde of him pite. 146 Þan seyd þe pilgrim, ‘þou hast gret wrong To frain me of mi sorwe strong, & mi?t no?t bete mi nede. To begge mi brede y mot gon: Seþþen ?istay at none ete y non, Also god me rede.’ ‘?is, felawe,’ quaþ Gij, ‘hele it nau?t. Telle me whi þou art in sorwe brau?t: Þe better þou schalt spede; & seþþen we schul go seche our mete. Ichaue a pani of old bi?ete: Þou schalt haue half to mede.’ 147 ‘Gramerci, sir,’ þan seyd he; ‘& alle þe soþ y schal telle þe. Erl Tirri is mi name, Of Gormoys þerls sone Aubri. Ich hadde a felawe þat hi?t Gij, A baroun of gode fame. For þe douk of Paui sir Otoun Hadde don him oft gret tresoun, He slou? him wiþ gret grame. Now is his neue þemperour steward, His soster sone, þat hat Berard: He has me don alle þis schame. 148 Þemperour he haþ serued long. For he is wonderliche strong & of michel mi?t, He no comeþ in non batayle Þat he no haþ þe maistri, saunfayl: So egre he is to fi?t. In þis warld is man non Þat o?aines him durst gon, Herl, baroun, no kni?t, & he loked on him wiþ wrake, Þat his hert no mi?t quake: So stern he is of si?t. 149 & for his scherewdhed sir Berard Þemperour haþ made him his steward, To wardi his lond about. Þer nis no douk in al þis lond Þat his hest dar wiþ-stonde: So michel he is dout. ?if a man be loued wiþ him, Be he neuer so pouer of kin, & he wil to him lout, He makeþ hem riche anon ri?t, Douk, erl, baroun, or kni?t, To held wiþ him gret rout. 150 & ?if a man wiþ him hated be, Be he neuer so riche of fe, He flemeþ him out of lond: Anon he schal ben to-drawe, Als tite he schal ben y-slawe, & driuen him al to schond. So it bifel, our emperour Held a parlement of gret honour: For his erls he sent his sond. Y come þider wiþ michel prede Wiþ an hundred kni?tes bi mi side, At nede wiþ me to stonde. 151 & when y come vnto þe court Þe steward, þe wicked pourt, To me he gan to reke: He bicleped me of his emes ded, & seyd he was sleyn þurch mi red: On me he wald be wreke. &, when ich herd þat chesoun Of þe doukes deþ Otoun, Mine hert wald to-breke. To þemperour y layd mi wedde an hei?e To defende me of þat felonie Þat he to me gan speke. 152 No wonder þei y war fordredde. Þemperour tok boþe our wedde, As y þe telle may. For in alle þe court was þer no wi?t, Douk, erl, baroun, no kni?t, Þat durst me borwe þat day, Þemperour comand anon Into his prisoun y schuld be don Wiþ-outen more delay. Berard went, & sesed mi lond; Mine wiif he wald haue driuen to schond: Wiþ sorwe sche fled oway. 153 Þan was ich wiþ sorwe & care Among min fomen nomen þare, & don in strong prisoun. Min frendes token hem to rede, To þemperour þai bisou?t & bede To pay for me ransoun. Þemperour & sir Berard Deliuerd me bi a forward & bi þis enchesoun, Y schuld seche mi felawe Gij, To defende ous of þat felonie Of þe doukes deþ Otoun. 154 Out of þis lond went y me, & passed ouer þe salt se: In Inglond y gan riue. At Warwike ichim sou?t: When y com þider y fond him nou?t (Wo was me oliue), No sir Herhaud fond y nou?t tare: To seche Gyes sone he is fare, Þat was stollen wiþ striue. Þerfore y wot þat Gij is ded: For sorwe can y me no red; Mine hert wil breke o fiue.’ 155 Sir Gij biheld Tirri ful ri?t, Þat whilom was so noble a kni?t, & lord of michel mounde. His bodi, was sumtim wele y-schredde, Almost naked it was bihedde, Wiþ sorwe & care ful bounde. His legges, þat wer sumtime hosed wel, To-brosten he sei?e hem eueridel. ‘Allas,’ seyd Gij, ‘þat stonde.’ For sorwe þat he hadde þo Word mi?t he speke no mo, Bot fel aswon to grounde. 156 Sir Tirri anon com to him þan, & in his armes vp him nam, & cleped opon him þare. ‘Man,’ he said, ‘what aileþ þe? Þou art iuel at aise, so þenkeþ me. Hard it is þi fare.’ Sir Gij answerd þer-after long, ‘Þis iuel greueþ me so strong, In erþe y wold y ware; For, seþþen þat y was first man, Nas neuer sorwe on me cam Þat greued me so sare.’ 157 Þan seyd Tirri, ‘felawe, y-wis, To-day a ?er gon it is Out of þis lond y went To seche Gij, mi gode frende, Y no finde nou?t fer no hende: Þerfore icham al schent; For now it is teld me our emperer Haþ taken a parlement of þis maner For mi loue, verrament, Þat douk no erl in his lond be, Þat he no schal be at þat semble, For to here mi iugement. 158 & now no lenge abide y no may, Þat ne me bi-houeþ hom þis day, Oþer for to lese min hed. Þemperour ichaue mi treuþe y-pli?t, Y schal bring sir Gij to-ni?t To fi?t o?ain þat qued, To fende ous of þat felonie O?ain þe douke Berard of Paui Al of his emes ded. Y wot wele, ?if y þider fare, Þai schal me sle wiþ sorwe & care: Certes, y can no red.’ 159 Gij biheld Tirri wiþ wepeand ei?e, & sei?e him al þat sorwe drei?e, Þat was him lef & dere: ‘Allas,’ þou?t Gij, ‘þat ich stounde Þat Tirri is þus brou?t to grounde! So gode felawes we were.’ He þou?t, ‘mi?t y mete þat douke, His heued y schuld smite fro þe bouke, Or hong him bi þe swere. Y no lete for al þis warldes won Þat y no schuld þe traitour slon, To wreke Tirri, mi fere. 160 Tirri,’ seyd Gij, ‘lat be þi þou?t: Y-wis, it helpeþ þe ri?t nou?t, For sorwe it wil þe schende. To court go we boþe y-fere: Gode tidinges we schul þer here; Swiche grace god may sende. Haue gode hert, dred þe no del; For god schal help þe ful wel: So curteys he is & hende.’ Up risen þo kni?tes tvo Wiþ michel care & ful of wo: To court ward þai gan wende. 161 & as þai went þo kni?tes fre To court ward in her iurne Ful bold þai were & ?epe. ‘Allas,’ sir Tirri seyd þo, ‘Ich mot rest er ich hennes go, Or mi liif wil fro me lepe.’ ‘For god, felawe,’ þan seyd Gij, ‘Ly doun, & y schal sitt þe bi, & feir þine heued vp kepe.’ & when he hadde þus y-seyd On Gyes barm his heued he leyd: Anon Tirri gan slepe. 162 & when sir Tirri was fallen on slepe Sir Gij biheld him, & gan to wepe, & gret morning gan make. Þan sei?e he an ermine com of his mouþe Als swift als winde, þat bloweþ on clouþe, As white as lilii on lake. To an hille he ran wiþouten obade: At þe hole of þe roche in he glade. Gij wonderd for þat sake. & when he out of þat roche cam Into Tirries mouþe he nam: Anon Tirri gan wake. 163 Sir Gij was wonderd of þat si?t, & Tirri sat vp anon ri?t, & biheld Gij opon. Þan seyd Tirri, ‘fader of heuen! Sir pilgrim, swiche a wonder sweuen Me met now anon, Þat to ?on hille þat stont on hei?e, Þat þou may se wiþ þi nei?e, Me þou?t þat y was gon, & at an hole in y wond, & so riche tresour as y fond Y trow in þis world is non. 164 Biside þat tresour lay a dragoun, & þer-on lay a swerd broun, Þe sckauberk comly corn: In þe hilt was mani precious ston, As bri?t as ani sonne it schon, Wiþ-outen oþ y-sworn. & me þou?t Gij sat at min heued, & in his lappe me biweued Astow dest me biforn. Lord, merci, & it wer so Wele were me þan bi-go, Þat euer ?ete was y born.’ 165 ‘Now, felawe,’ seyd Gij, ‘bi mi leute, Þat s[w]euen wil turn gret ioie to þe, & wele y schal it rede: Þurch Gij þou schalt þi lond keuer. Trust wele to god, þei þou be pouer: Þe better þou schalt spede. To þe hulle nim we þe way, Þer þe þou?t þe tresour lay, & in þou schalt me lede. Now god, þat schope al mankinde, Wald we mi?t þat tresour finde: It wald help ous at nede.’ 166 Vp risen þo kni?tes tvay, & to þe hille þai nom þe way, & in þai went ful euen, & founde þe tresour, & þe dragoun, & þe swerd of stiel broun, As Tirri met in his sweuen. Sir Gij drou? out þat swerd anon, & alle þe pleynes þer-of it schon, As it were li?t of leuen. ‘Lord,’ seyd Gij, ‘y þanke þi sond: Y sei?e neuer are swiche a brond; Y wot it com fram heuen.’ 167 Sir Gij gan þe hilt bi-hold, Þat richeliche was grauen wiþ gold, Of charbukel þe pomel. Into þe sckaweberk o?ain he it dede, & seyd to Tirri in þat stede, ‘Bi god & seyn Mi?hel, Of alle þis riche tresore Y no kepe þerof no more, Bot þis brond of stiel.’ 168 To courtward þo kni?tes went: To aspie after þe parlement For drede wald þai nou?t lete. Ac Tirri was aferd ful sare Of his fomen be knowen þare, In þe cite ?if he sete; Þerfore þai toke her ostel gode At an hous wiþouten þe toun stode Al bi a dern strete. Of al ni?t Gij slepe nou?t: So michel his hert was euer in þou?t Wiþ douk Berard to mete. 169 Erlich amorwe þan ros Gij, & bisou?t god & our leuedi He schuld scheld him fro blame, & seyd to sir Tirri þe hende, ‘Kepe me wele þis swerd, leue frende, Til y sende þer-fore, bi name, & y schal go to court þis day, & ?if y þe douke mete may Y schal gret him wiþ grame, & ?if he say ou?t bot gode Bi him þat schadde for ous his blod, Him tit a warld schame.’ 170 Gij goþ to toun wiþ michel hete: Þemperour fram chirche he gan mete, & gret him wiþ anour. ‘Lord’ seyd Gij, ‘þat wiþ hond Made wode, water, & lond, Saue þe, sir emperour. Icham a man of fer cuntre, & of þi gode par charite Ich axse to mi socour.’ Þemperour seyd, ‘to court come, & of mi gode þou schalt haue some For loue of seyn sauour.’ 171 To court þai went al & some. Þemperour dede Gij biforn him come: ‘Pilgrim,’ þan seyd he, ‘Þou art wel weri meþenkeþ now: Fram wiche londes comestow? For þi fader soule, telle me.’ ‘Sir,’ seyd Gij, ‘ich vnderstond, Ichaue ben in mani lond Bi?ond þe Grekis se: In Ierusalem & in Surry, In Costentin & in Perci A gode while haue ich be.’ 172 ‘Sir pilgrim,’ seyd þemperour fre, ‘What spekeþ man in þat lond of me When þou com þennes ward?’ Sir Gij answerd, ‘bi þe gode rode, Men spekeþ þe þer ful litel gode, Bot tidinges schrewed & hard; For þou hast schent so þerl Tirri & oþer barouns, þat ben hendy, For loue of þi steward. Gret sinne it is to þe To stroye so þi barouns fre Al for a fals schreward.’ 173 When þe douk herd him speke so, As a wilde bore he lepe him to, His costes for to schawe. Wiþ his fest he wald haue smiten Gij, Bot barouns held him owy Wele tventi on a rawe. He seyd to Gij, ‘vile traitour, Ner þou bifor þemperour, Þei y wende to ben to-hewe, Bi thi berd y schuld þe schokke, Þat al þi teþ it schuld rokke; For þou art a kinde schrewe. 174 Bi þi semblaunt se men may Þou hast ben traitour mani a day: God ?if þe schame & schond. ?if þat y þe mai ouergon, To wicked ded þou schalt be don, As a traitour to ly in bond: In swiche a stede þou schalt be, Þis seuen winter no schaltow se Noiþer fet no hond. So schal men chasti foule glotuns Þat wil missay gode barouns Þat lordinges ben in lond.’ 175 ‘Ow sir,’ seyd Gij, ‘ertow þas? Y nist no nar ho it was, Bi þe gode rode, & now y wot þat þou art he: Þou art vncurteys, so þenkeþ me. Þou farst astow wer wode, & art a man of fair parage: Y-com þou art of hei?e linage & of gentil blod. It is þe litel curteysie To do me swiche vilanie Bifor þemperour þer y stode. 176 & for þe wil y wond no-þing: Y schal telle þe þe soþe wiþouten lesing Bifor his barouns ichon, Þat wiþ gret wrong & sinne, ywis, Þerl Tirri deshirrite is & oþer gode mani on. A þousend men ichaue herd teld Boþe in toun & in feld, As wide as ichaue gon, Þat he is giltles of þat dede: Þou berst on him wiþ falshede Þi neme he schuld slon.’ 177 Þe douk Berra[r]d was wroþ, Bi Iesu Crist he swore his oþ, ‘Y wald þat þou were Gij, Or þat þou so douhti were Þou durst fi?t for him here: God ?af it & our leuedi!’ Sir Gij answerd, ‘bi seyn sauour, Drede þe noþing, vile traitour: Þerto icham redy. Bi þou wroþ, be þou gladde, To þemperour y ?if mi wedde To fi?t for þerl Tirri.’ 178 Þe douk Berard þer he stode Stared on Gij as he wer wode, & egrelich seyd his þou?t. ‘Pilgrim,’ he seyd, ‘þou art ful stout: Y-wis, þi wordes þat er so prout Schal be ful dere abou?t. Y warn þe wele,’ he seyd þo, ‘Þat þine heued þou schalt forgo, Where so þou may be sou?t.’ Sir Gij seyd, ‘þan þou it hast, Þan make þer-of þi bast; For ?ete no getes þou it nou?t.’ 179 Bifor þemperour þan come Gij, & seyd, ‘sir Berard of Paui Is a man of mi?ti dede, & fram fer cuntres comen icham, & am a sely pouer man: Y no haue here no sibbered, No y no haue wepen no armour bri?t. For þe loue of god al-mi?t, Finde me armour & stede.’ Þemperour answerd, ‘bi Iesu, Pilgrim, þou schalt haue anow Of al þat þe is nede.’ 180 Þe douk Berra[r]d þennes he went: His hert was in strong turment, He no wist what he do mi?t. Þemperour cleped his douhter, a mayde: ‘Leue douhter,’ to hir he seyd, ‘Kepe þis pilgrim to-ni?t.’ Sche him vnderfenge ful mildeliche, & dede baþe him ful softliche: In silke sche wald him di?t, Ac þerof was no-þing his þou?t, Bot of gode armour he hir bisou?t, Wiþ þe douke Berard to fi?t. 181 Amorwe aros þat emperour: Erls, barouns of gret honour To chirche wiþ him þai ?ede, & when þe barouns asembled was Þan mi?t men sen in þat plas To-gider a fair ferred. Þider com þe douk Berard Prout & stern as a lipard, Wele y-armed on stede, & priked ri?t as he wer wode Among þe barouns þer þai stode, Batayle for to bede. 182 Þe maiden for?at neuer a del, Þe pilgrim was armed ful wel Wiþ a gode glaiue in honde, & a swift ernand stede Al wrin sche dede him lede, Þe best of þat lond. Þat sir Gij him bi-þou?t, Þe gode swerd for?at he nou?t Þat he in tresour fond. He sent þerafter priueliche (Noman wist litel no miche), & Tirri sent him þe brond. 183 When þat mayden hadde graiþed Gij, Wele y-di?t & ful richely, Men gan on him biheld. Sche ledde him forþ swiþe stille To þemperour wiþ gode wille: Sche tau?t him for to weld. Þan seyd þemperour hende & fre, ‘Lordinges, listen now to me, Boþe ?ong & eld. Þis kni?t, þat ?e se now here, Haþ taken batail in strong maner, Al for to fi?t in feld. 184 Þis kni?t,’ he seyd, ‘þat ston[t] me bi, Wil fi?t for þerl sir Tirri (For no þing wil he wond), & defende him of þat felonie O?ain þe douk Berard of Paui Þat he berþ him an hond; For Tirri is out of lond went To seche Gij, verrament, Þat for him mi?t stond (Þis day is sett bitven hem tvo), Or be deshirrite for euer-mo, & flemed out of lond. 185 Bot now is comen here þis kni?t, O?ain Berard haþ taken þe fi?t: For no þing wil he flen. Ac, lordinges,’ he seyd, ‘euerichon, Where the batayl schal be don Loke, where it may best ben.’ Þan loked þai it schuld be In a launde vnder þe cite. Þider in þai went bi-den: Mani man bad god þat day Help þe pilgrim, as he wele may, Þe douk Berard to slen. 186 On hors lopen þo kni?tes prest, & lopen to-gider til schaftes brest, Þat strong weren & trewe, & her gerþes brusten, þat strong were, & þo kni?tes boþe y-fere Out of her sadels þrewe. After þai drou? her swerdes gode, & leyd on as þai were wode, Þat were gode & newe; & astow sest þe fir on flint Þe stem out of her helmes stint So hetelich þai gun hewe. 187 Wele wer armed þo kni?tes stout, Bot he had more yren him about Þat fals Berardine: Tvay hauberkes he was in weued, & tvay helmes opon his heued, Was wrou?t in Sarazine. Opon his schulder henge a duble scheld (Better mi?t non be born in feld), A gode swerd of stiel fine: Mani man þerwiþ his liif had lorn. It was sumtim þer-biforn Þe kinges Costentine. 188 Strong batayl held þo kni?tes bold, Þat alle þat euer gan hem bihold Þai seyden hem among Þe pilgrim was non erþely man; It was an angel, from heuen cam For Tirri batayle to fong: ‘For mani gode erle & mani baroun Berard haþ y-brou?t adoun Wiþ wel michel wrong, Þer-fore haþ God sent, y-wis, An angel out of heuen blis To sle þat traitour strong.’ 189 Al þe folk in þat cite was, Litel & michel, more & las, To se þe batayl þai ?ede; Bot Tirri in a chirche liis, & euer he bisou?t god, y-wis, He schuld him help & spede. When he herd telle [þat a] pilgrim Fau?t o?ain þe douke Berardin, To help him at his nede, Wel fain he wald þider gon, Bot for knoweing of his fon: Wel sore he gan him drede. 190 Ac naþeles he ros vp þo Wiþ michel care & michel wo, & þider he went wel swiþe. When he com to þe plas Þer þe bataile loked was, Amonges hem he gan liþe, &, when he sey?e the douk so strong & his armes to-hewe among, In his hert he was ful bliþe, &, þo he sey?e his blod spille, God he þonked wiþ gode wille. 191 ‘Lord, merci!’ Tirri gan say: ‘Þis is nou?t þe pilgrim y met ?isterday Þat is so richeliche di?t. He was a feble pouer body, Sely, messays, & hungri; & he is of michel mi?t. Y trow non erþelich man it be. On Gij y þenke when ichim se: So douhti he was in fi?t. ?if Gij, mi felawe, nou?t ded nere, Ich wald sigge þat he it were: So liche þai ben of si?t.’ 192 Into chirche o?ain he ?ede, & fel on knes in þat stede, & Iesus Crist he bi-sou?t He schuld help þe pilgrim Þat fau?t o?ain douk Berardin, Þat miche wo haþ him wrou?t. Hard togider gun þai fi?t Fro the morwe to þe ni?t, Þat þai rest hem nou?t; & when hem failed li?t of day Þai couþe no rede what þai do may: To þemperour þai hem brou?t. 193 ‘Sir emperour,’ þai seyd anon, ‘What schul we wiþ þis kni?tes don? At þi wille schal it be.’ Þemperour clept to him þo Four barouns þat his trust was to. ‘Lordinges,’ þan seyd he, ‘Kepe me wele þe douk Berard, & bring him tomorwe bi a forward, Opon al ?our fe. & y schal kepe þe pilgrim to-ni?t: Til tomorwe þat it is day li?t He schal bileue wiþ me.’ 194 Þan departed þis batayle: Þo four barouns, wiþ-outen fayl, Vnder-stode Berard to kepe, & þemperour toke þe pilgrim, In a chaumber to loken him Wiþ seriaunce wise & ?epe. Þe douke Berard for-?at him nou?t, Of a foule tresoun he him bi-þou?t: Four kni?tes he gan clepe. ‘F[or] mi loue,’ he seyd, ‘goþ to-ni?t Þ[er] þe pilgrim liþ ful ri?t, & sleþ him in his slepe.’ 195 Þai armed hem swiþe wel Boþe in iren & in stiel, & went hem forþ in hast. Into þe chaumber þai went anon: Þe pilgrims kepers euerichon Lay & slepe full fast. To þe pilgrim þai went ful ri?t, & left vp þe bedde wiþ her mi?t, Þo four traitours vnwrast: To þe se þai beren him, & boþe bed & þe pilgrim Into þe see þai cast. 196 To sir Berard þai went anon, & teld him hou þai hadden don; Þerof he was ful fawe. ‘Sir,’ þai seyd, ‘be nou?t adred: Boþe þe pilgrim & þe bed, Into þe se we han y-þrawe.’ Þe pilgrim waked, & loked an hey?e: Þe sterres on þe heuen he sei?e, Þe water about him drawe. Þei he was ferd no wonder it nis: Non oþer þing he no sey?e, y-wis, Bot winde & wateres wawe. 197 ‘Lord,’ seyd Gij, ‘god almi?t, Þat winde, & water, & al þing di?t, On me haue now pite! Whi is me fallen þus strong cumbring? & y no fi?t for to win no þing, Noiþer gold no fe, For no cite no no castel, Bot for mi felawe y loued so wel, Þat was of gret bounte. For he was sumtyim so douhti, & now he is so pouer a bodi, Certes, it reweþ me.’ 198 Now herkeneþ a litel striif, Hou he saued þe pilgrims liif Iesu, þat sitt in trone, Wiþ a fischer þat was comand, In þe se fische takeand Bi himself al-on. He seþ þat bed floter him by: ‘On godes half,’ he gan to cri, ‘What artow? say me son.’ Þe pilgrim his heued vp pli?t, & crid to him anon ri?t, & made wel reweli mon. 199 ‘Gode man,’ þan seyd he, ‘Y leue on god in trinite: Þe soþe þou schalt now sen. Vnderstode þou ou?t of þe batayl hard Bitven þe pilgrim & sir Berard, Hou þai fou?ten bitven?’ Þe fischer seyd, ‘y sei?e þe fi?t Fro þe morwe to þe ni?t: For noþing wald þai flen. Þemperour comand þo Þai schuld be kept boþe tvo, Tomorwe bring hem o?en.’ 200 ‘Icham,’ he seyd, ‘þe pilgrim Þat fau?t wiþ þe douke Berardin For Tirri, þe hendi kni?t. ?istreuen we wer deled ato; In a chaumber y was do Wiþ seriaunce wise & wi?t: Hou ich com her no wot y nou?t. For his loue þat þis warld haþ wrou?t, Saue me ?if þou mi?t.’ Þe fischer tok him into his bot anon, & to his hous he ladde him hom, & saued his liif þat ni?t. 201 Þemperour ros amorwe, y-wis, & at þe chirche he herd his messe In þe first tide of þe day, & into his halle he gan gon, & after þe steward he axed anon & þe pilgrim wiþ-outen delay. Þe four barouns for?at hem nou?t, Þe douke Berard þai han forþ brou?t Redy armed to play; & þe pilgrims kepers com euerichon, & seyd to þemperour, bi seyn Ion, Þe pilgrim was oway. 202 Þemperour was wel wroþ: Bi his fader soule he swore his oþ, Þai schuld ben hang & drawe. ‘For godes loue,’ he seyd, ‘merci! Þis douke Berard of Paui Haþ him brou?t o dawe.’ Þemperour seyd, ‘bi seyn Martin, Hastow don þis fals, Berardin, To don þe pilgrim slawe? ?eld him deþes or liues to me, Or in mi court demp[t] þou schalt be Þurch iugement of lawe.’ 203 Þe douke Berard wex wroþ & wo; Þemperour he answerd þo Wiþ wel michel hete: ‘Ichaue serued þe long, sir emperour, & kept þi londes wiþ michel anour, & now þou ginnest me þrete. Þerof ?iue y nou?t a chirston. Hom to Lombardy ichil gon: Wiþ alle þe ost y may gete Y schal com in-to Almayn; for al þi tene Of al þi lond, siker mot þou ben, O fot y no schal þe lete.’ 204 When þemperour herd þat, & of his þretening vnder-?at, He bad wiþ wordes bold Out of his court he schuld gon. & he answerd sone anon Þat sikerliche he nold. Þer com þe fischer priueliche, & puked þemperour softliche: His tale to him he told. ‘Sir emperour,’ he seyd, ‘listen to me: Of þe pilgrim ichil telle þe, ?if þou me herken wold.’ 205 ‘Fischer,’ seyd þemperour fre, ‘Of þe pilgrim telle þou me, ?if þou þe soþe can sayn.’ ‘For-soþe,’ he seyd, ‘y can ful wel: Y schal þe ley?en neuer a del; Þerof icham ful fain. ?istreuen, wiþ-outen lesing, Y went to þe se of fischeing, Mine nettes for to layn. A bedde y fond þer floterand, & þer-on a kni?t liggeand, A man of michel mayn. 206 & ich him axed what he were: He told me þe soþe þere Wiþ wordes fre & hende. ‘Icham,’ he seyd, ‘þe pilgrim Þat fau?t wiþ þe douke Berardin ?isterday to þe nende.’ Y tok him into mi bot anon, & to min hous y lad him hom, & kept him as mi frende. ?if þou leuest nou?t he is þare, Do sum seriaunt þider fare, & þer ?e may him fende.’ 207 Þemperour sent after him þo Wiþ þe fischer & other mo, & brou?t him, saunfayle. Þai were don togider bliue Wiþ hard strokes for to driue: Þai gun hem to asayle. Wel hard togider gun þai fi?t: Wiþ her brondes, þat wer bri?t, Þai hewe hauberk of mayle. Þus togider gun þai play, Til it was þe hey?e midday, Wiþ wel strong batayle. 208 Þe douk Berard was egre of mode: He smot to Gij as he wer wode; His liif he wende to winne. He hit [him] on þe helm on hi?t, Þat alle þe floures feir & bri?t He dede hem fley?e atvinne. Þe nasel he carf atvo, & þe venteyle he dede also Ri?t to his bare chinne. Three lines are omitted here in the MS. 209 Sir Gij was wroþ anon fot hot, & Berard on þe helme he smot: To stond hadde he no space; For boþe helmes he carf atvo, & his heued he dede also In midward of þe face. Þurch al his bodi þe swerd bot Into þe erþe wele half a fot, Þat sei?e men in þe place. Þ[e s] oule went fro þe bodi þere: Þ[e fol]k of þe cite wel glad were; Þ[ai] þonked our lordes grace. 210 Bifor þemperour þan com sir Gij: ‘Ichaue wroken þerl Tirri (Þe soþe þou mi?t now sen), & defended him of þat felonie O?ain þe douke Berard of Paui, Þat was so stout & ken. Þerfore þe soþe ich ax þe, ?if Tirri schal quitecleymed be, & haue his lond o?en. & who so þer-o?ain wiþstond He schal haue schame of min hond, Wel siker may he ben.’ 211 Þemperour seyd, ‘sikerly, Þou hast wroken þerl Tirri; Gret honour þou hast him don. Þerfore when he is come His londes þan al & some He schal haue euerichon.’ Þan was Gij glad & bliþe, & kest of his armes also swiþe: After him he thou?t to gon. Þemperour wald cloþe him in gold, Ac, sikerliche, he seyd he nold: His sclauain he axed anon. 212 To toun he went in his way To finde Tirri ?if he may In sorwe & care ful bounde. Into a chirche he him dede, & fond him in a priue stede Liand on knes to grounde. ‘Arise vp, Tirri,’ he seyd þo; ‘To court þou schalt wiþ me go, Now ichaue þe founde.’ Tirri anon his heued vpbreyd, & seyd, ‘pilgrim, hastow me treyd, Allas þat ich stounde! 213 Allas, allas,’ þan seyd he, ‘To what man may men trust be, To chese to his make? Þou þat semed so stedefast To þemperour me wraied hast: To sle me þou hast take. In iuel time was it to me Þat y mi name told to þe: Allas þat ich sake!’ For sorwe þat he hadde þo O word no mi?t he speke mo, Bot stode & gan to quake. 214 ‘Tirri,’ seyd Gij, ‘drede þe no-þing: Þou schalt to-day here gode tiding Þurch grace of godes sond. Þe schrewed douke Berard he is ded; Under þe cite he is y-leyde: Y slou? him wiþ min hond.’ Þo was Tirri glad & bliþe: To court he went also swiþe; For noþing wald he wond. ‘Sir emperour,’ seyd Gij anon, ‘Now is Tirri comen hom To resceiue his lond.’ 215 Þemperour on him gan bihold, & seyd to him wiþ wordes bold, ‘Artow þerl Tirri? Where is now þi bold chere Þat whilom so douhti were, & holden so hardi?’ ‘?a, sir,’ he seyd, ‘icham he. Whilom y was of gret bounde, & helden ful douhti; & now ich haue al forlorn Wiþ miche sorwe on euen & morn To seke mi felawe sir Gij. 216 Ich haue him sou?t in mani lond, Ac neuer man ?ete ich fond Can telle of him no sawe: He is dede, ich wot full wel. God almi?ti & seyn Mi?hel To blis his soule drawe! Ac now is it told me þis pilgrim As slayn þe douke Berardin; Þerof icham ful fawe. Sir emperour, y bid merci: For godes loue & our leuedi, Þo[u] do me londes lawe.’ 217 Þritti erls wel curteys, & alle þe lordinges of þe palais, & mani baroun afine Crid merci to þemperour bold. Þemperour gan him bihold, & seyd, ‘Tirri, frende min, Here y sese þe in al þi lond, Wiþ worþschip to held in þine hond, Bi god & seyn Martine. Bifor mi barouns y graunt þe, Steward of mi lond þou schalt be As was þe douke Berardine.’ 218 Þemperour kist him ful swete, For?af him his wreþe & his hete Bifor hem al þere. When þemperour & þerl were at on, Þe lordinges euerichon Wele bliþe of hertes were. ‘Sir Tirri,’ seyd þemperour fre, ‘For þi fader soule, tel þou me, Astow art me leue & dere, Whennes is þis pilgrim? Is he þi nem or þi cosyin Þat fau?t for þe here?’ 219 ‘Sir emperour,’ seyd sir Tirri, ‘So god me help & our leuedi, For-soþe wiþouten fayle, Y no sei?e neuer ere þis pilgrim, Bot þis oþer day y met wiþ him, & told him mi conseyl. He swore astite bi seyn Ion To þi court he wald gon Þe douk Berard to asayle. Ich wend wel litel þan, y pli?t, He hadde ben of michel mi?t, To hold wiþ him batayle.’ 220 Þemperour dede as a gode man, & Tirri into his chaumber he nam, & richeliche gan him schrede. He fond him wepen, & armour bri?t, & al þat schuld falle to kni?t, & feffed him wiþ prede; & fond him hors & stedes gode, Of al his lond þe best stode, Hom wiþ him to lede. Þemperour wald þe pilgrim at-hold, Ac, sikerliche, he seyd he nold: Wiþ Tirri hom he ?ede. 221 When Tirri was comen hom, Þe pilgrim he wald anon Sesen in al his lond, & he for-soke it al out-ri?t; For riches loued he no-wi?t For to hold in hond. Þerl as swiþe his sond he sent Ouer al his lond, verrament, Til þat his wiif he fond: Þo was sche founden in an ile In a nunri þat while For doute of Berardes bond. 222 Þo was Tirri a noble man, In al þat lond better nas nan, As y ?ou tel may. Destrud were al his enemis: He liueþ in michel ioie & blis, Al-so a prince in play. Anon sir Gij him bi-þou?t Þat lenger wald he duelle nou?t. To sir Tirri on a day He seyd to him in þat tide, ‘Here nil y no lenger abide: Ich mot wende in mi way. 223 O þing,’ he seyd, ‘y pray þe: Out of þe cite go wiþ me, Astow art hendi kni?t. Alon we shul go boþe y-fere, & swich tidinges þou schalt here, Þou schalt haue wonder, apli?t.’ Þerl him graunt wiþ hert fre, & went wiþ him out of þat cite In his way ful ri?t, & when þai wer þennes half a mile Þer þai duelled a litel while, Þo gomes of michel mi?t. 224 ‘Tirri,’ seyd Gij, ‘vnderstond þou þe: Þou art vnkinde, so þenkeþ me; For Gij, þi gode fere, Whi wiltow him knowe nou?t? Y-wis, þou art iuel biþou?t. No was he þe leue & dere? Þenke he slou? þe douk Otoun, & brou?t þe out of his prisoun, & made þe quite & skere, & hou he fond þe ded almast As he rode þurch a forest Wiþ a rewely chere, 225 & hou he socourd þi leman schene, & al þe fiften outlawes ken He slou? hem al on rawe, & slou? þe four kni?tes radde, & þi bodi to toun ladde, To leche þi woundes ful fawe, & he socourd þi fader in wer, & halp þe boþe nere & fer Þo þou was fallen ful lawe, & now y slou? Berard þe strong. Icham Gij; þou hast wrong: Why wiltow me nou?t knawe?’ 226 When þerl herd him speke so, Wepen he gan wiþ ey?en to, & fel aswon to grounde. ‘For godes loue,’ he seyd, ‘merci! Iuel at ese now am y, In sorwe & care ful bounde. Ful wele mi?t y knowe þe ar now: In al þis warld was non bot þou O?ain Berard durst founde. Merci, sir, par charite: Þat ich haue misknowen þe, Allas, allas þat stounde!’ 227 Merci he crid on his kne: Boþe for sorwe & for pite Wepen he bigan. He sey?e his legges brosten ich-del, Þat whilom wer y-hosed ful wel: More sorwe made neuer man. Sir Gij went to him þo: In his hert him was wo, & in his armes vp him nam. Atvix hem was gret diol in þat stounde: Boþe þai fel aswon to grounde: For sorwe þai wex al wan. 228 ‘Tirri,’ seyd sir Gij þo, ‘Þou schalt bileue, & y schal go: Y biteche þe heuen king. Bot ich haue a sone, y-wis, Y not wheþer he kni?t is, For he is bot a ?ongling: ?if he haue ani nede to þe, Help him for þe loue of me, Y pray þe, in al þing. Ich hope he schal be a gode kni?t: Y pray Iesu ful of mi?t He graunt him his blisceing.’ 229 ‘Merci, sir,’ þan seyd he, ‘For godes loue, leue her stil wiþ me: Y pray þe par amour. Mi treuþe y pli?t in þine hond, Y schal þe sese in al mi lond, Boþe in toun & tour. Þi man y wil be & serue þe ay Þer while mi liif lest may, To hold vp þin honour. & ?if þou no wilt ichil wiþ þe go: Y-wis, ichaue wele leuer so Þan bileue wiþ þemperour.’ 230 ‘Do oway, sir Tirri: þer-of speke nou?t; Al idel speche it is þi þou?t. Wende o?ain hom now ri?t, & be nou?t to prout, y þe rede: To serue þi lord at al his nede Þou proue wiþ þi mi?t. Desirite no man of his lond: ?if þou dost þou gos to schond; Ful siker be þou, apli?t. For ?iue þou reue a man his fe Godes face schaltow neuer se, No com in heuen li?t. 231 Biþenke þe wele of douke Berard, Hou prout he was, for he was steward, & flemed þe out of lond, & he now desirite is, Wiþ michel sorwe slayn, y-wis, & schamelich driuen to schond. Y schal gon, & þou bileue schalt: Y biteche þe god, þat al þing walt, & maked wiþ his hond.’ Þai kisten hem togider þo: Oliue þai sey?en hem neuer eft mo, As þe gest doþ ous vnderstond. 232 Gret sorwe þai made at her parting, & kist hem wiþ ei?e wepeing. Þai wenten hem boþe atvo. Als swiþe þerl Tirri went him hom, Þre days he no ete mete non: In hert him was ful wo; & when þe countas, sikerly, Herd seyn it was sir Gij Þat þan was went hem fro, Sche vpbreyd hir lord day & ni?t Þat he no had holden him wiþ strengþe & mi?t, & laten him nou?t þennes go. 233 Now went Gij forþ in his way Toward þe see so swiþe he may; For Tirri he siked sare. Into schip he went biliue: Ouer þe se he gan driue; Into Inglond he gan fare. Þe lond folk he axed anon After king Aþelston, In what cuntre he ware. ‘At Winchester, verrament, & after his barouns he haþ sent Boþe lasse & mare. 234 Erls, barouns, & bischopes, Kni?tes, priours, & abbotes At Winchester þai ben ichon, & han puruayd, wiþ-outen lesing, Þre days to ben in fasting, To biseke god in tron He sende hem þurch his swet sond A man þat were douhti of hond O?ain Colbrond to gon. Þer is þe king & þe barnage, y-wis, For doute of her enemis, Þat wayt hem for to slon. 235 For sir Anlaf, þe king of Danmark, Wiþ a nost store & stark Into Inglond is come, Wiþ fiften þousend kni?tes of pris: Alle þis lond þai stroyen, y-wis, & mani a toun han nome. A geaunt he haþ brou?t wiþ him Out of Aufrike stout & grim: Colbrond hat þat gome. For him is al Inglond forlore Bot godes help be bi-fore, Þat socour sende hem some. 236 To þe king he haþ sent his sond For to ?eld him al Inglond, & ?if him trowage out-ri?t; ?if he no wil nou?t, finde a baroun, A geaunt oþer a champioun, O?ain Colbrond to fi?t. & þer-of þai han taken a day, Ac our king non finde may: Erl, baroun, no kni?t, No squier, no seriaunt non O?ain þe geaunt dar gon: So grim he is of si?t.’ 237 Þan seyd sir Gij, ‘whare i[s] Herhaud, Þat in his time was so bald? & þai answerd ful swiþe, ‘To seche Gyes sone he is fare, Þat marchaunce hadde stollen þare: For him he was vnbliþe.’ ‘& where is þerl Rohaut of pris?’ & þai answerd, ‘dede he is, A gode while is go siþe; & Feliis, his douhter, is his air: So gode a leuedi no so fair, Y-wis, nis non oliue.’ 238 Gij went to Winchester a ful gode pas, Þer þe king þat time was, To held his parlement. Þe barouns weren in þe halle: Þe king seyd, ‘lordinges alle, Mine men ?e ben, verrament. Þerfore ich ax, wiþ-outen fayl, Of þis Danis folk, wil ous aseyl. Ich biseche ?ou wiþ gode entent, For godes loue y pray ?ou, Gode conseyl ?iue me now, Or elles we ben al schent. 239 For þe king of Danmark wiþ wrong Wiþ his geaunt, þat is so strong, He wil ous al schende. Þerfore ich axi ?ou ichon, What rede is best for to don? O?aines hem for to wende? ?if he ouercom ous in batayle He wil slen ous alle, saunfeyle, & strouen al our kende: Þan schal Inglond euermo Liue in þraldom & in wo Vnto þe warldes ende. 240 Þerfore ich axi ?ou now ri?t ?if ?e knowe our ani kni?t Þat is so stout & bold Þat þe batayle dar take an hond, To fi?t o?ain Col-brond: Half mi lond haue he schold Wiþ alle þe borwes þat liþ þer-to To him & to his aires euer-mo, To haue ?iue he wold.’ [S]til seten erls & barouns, As men hadde schauen her crounes: Nou?t on answere nold. 241 ‘Allas,’ seyd þe king, ‘þat y was born: Al mi ioie it is forlorn; Wel wo is me oliue. Now in al mi lond nis no kni?t O?ains a geant to hold fi?t: Mine hert wil breken on fiue. Allas, of Warwike sir Gij, Y no hadde ?euen þe half mi lond frely, To hold wiþouten striue! Wele were me þan bifalle, Ac, certes, now þe Danis men alle To sorwe þai schul me driue.’ 242 When it was ni?t to bedde þai ?ede: Þe king for sorwe & for drede Wiþ teres wett his lere. Of al þat ni?t he slepe ri?t nou?t, Bot euer Iesu he bisou?t, Þat was him leue & dere, He schuld him sende þurch his sond A man to fi?t wiþ Colbrond, ?if it is wille were; & Iesus Crist ful of mi?t He sent him a noble kni?t, As ?e may forward here. 243 Þer cam an angel fram heuen li?t, & seyd to þe king ful ri?t Þurch grace of godes sond. He seyd, ‘king Aþel-ston, slepestow? Hider me sent þe king Iesu To comfort þe to fond. To-morwe go to þe norþ ?ate ful swiþe: A pilgrim þou schalt se com biliue, When þou hast a while stond. Bid him for seynt Charite Þat he take þe batayl for þe, & he it wil nim on hond.’ 244 Þan was þe king glad & bliþe. A-morwe he ros vp ful swiþe, & went to þe gate ful ri?t; Tvay erls went wiþ him þo, & tvay bischopes dede also. Þe weder was fair & bri?t. Opon þe day about prime Þe king sei?e cum þe pilgrim. Bi þe sclauayn he him pli?t: ‘Pilgrim,’ he seyd, ‘y pray þe, To court wende þou hom wiþ me, & ostel þer al ni?t.’ 245 ‘Be stille, sir,’ seyd þe pilgrim: ‘It is nou?t ?ete time to take min in, Al-so god me rede.’ Þe king him bisou?t þo, & þe lordinges dede also: To court wiþ hem he ?ede. ‘Pilgrim,’ quaþ þe king, ‘par charite, ?if it be þi wil, vnderstond to me: Y schal schewe þe al our nede. Þe king of Danmark wiþ gret wrong Þurch a geaunt, þat is so strong, Wil strou al our þede. 246 & whe han taken of him batayle, On what maner, saunfayle, Y schal now tellen þe. Þurch þe bodi of a kni?t, O?ains þat geaunt to hold fi?t, Schal þis lond aquite be. &, pilgrim, for him þat dyed on rode, & þat for ous schadde his blod, To bigge ous alle fre, Take þe batayle now on hond, & saue ous þe ri?t of Inglond, For seynt Charite.’ 247 ‘Do way, leue sir,’ seyd Gij. ‘Icham an old man, a feble bodi: Mi strengþe is fro me fare.’ Þe king fel on knes to grounde, & crid him merci in þat stounde, ?if it his wille ware, & þe barouns dede also: O knes þai fellen alle þo Wiþ sorwe & sikeing sare. Sir Gij biheld þe lordinges alle, & whiche sorwe hem was bi-falle: Sir Gij hadde of hem care. 248 Sir Gij tok vp þe king anon, & bad þe lordinges euerichon Þat þai schuld vp stond, & seyd, ‘for god in trinite & for to make Inglond fre, Þe batayle y nim on hond.’ Þan was þe king ful glad & bliþe, & þonked Gij a þousend siþe & Iesu Cristes sond. To þe king of Danmark he sent þan, & seyd he hadde founden a man To fi?t for Inglond. 249 Þe Danismen busked hem ?are Into batayle for to fare: To fi?t þai war wel fawe. & Gij was armed swiþe wel In a gode hauberk of stiel Wrou?t of þe best lawe. An helme he hadde of michel mi?t With a ce[r]cle of gold, þat schon bri?t, Wiþ precious stones on rawe. In þe frunt stode a char-bukel ston: As bri?t as ani sonne it schon Þat glemes vnder schawe. 250 On þat helme stode a flour: Wrou?t it was of diuers colour; Mirie it was to b[i]hold. Trust & trewe was his ventayle, Gloues, & gambisoun, & hosen of mayle As gode kni?t haue scholde. Girt he was wiþ a gode brond Wele kerueand, bi-forn his hond A targe listed wiþ gold, Portreyd wiþ þre kinges corn, Þat present god when he was born: Mirier was non on mold. 251 & a swift ernand stede Al wrin þai dede him lede: His tire it was ful gay. Sir Gij opon þat stede wond Wiþ a gode glaiue in hond, & priked him forþ his way, &, when he com to þe plas Þer þe batayl loked was, Gij li?t wiþ-outen delay, & fel on knes doun in þat stede, & to god he bad his bede, He schuld ben his help þat day. 252 ‘Lord,’ seyd Gij, ‘þat rered Lazeroun, & for man þoled passioun, & on þe rode gan blede, Þat saued Sussan fram þe feloun, & halp Daniel fram þe lyoun, To-day wisse me & rede: Astow art mi?ti heuen king, To-day graunt me þi blisseing, & help me at þis nede. &, leuedi Mari ful of mi?t, To-day saue Inglondes ri?t, & leue me wele to spede.’ 253 When þe folk was samned bi boþe side, Þe to kinges wiþ michel pride After þe relikes þai sende, Þe corporas, & þe messe gere: On þe halidom þai gun swere Wiþ wordes fre & hende. Þe king of Danmarke swore furst, ywis, ?if þat his geant slayn is, To Danmarke he schal wende, & neuer more Inglond cum wiþinne, No non after him of his kinne Vnto þe warldes ende. 254 Seþþen swore þe king Aþelston, & seyd among hem euerichon Bi god þat al may weld, ?if his man þer slayn be, Or ouer-comen, þat men may se, Recreaunt in þe feld, His man he wil bicom an hond, & alle þe reme of Inglond Of him for to helde, & hold him for lord & king, Wiþ gold, & siluer, & oþer þing Gret trowage him for to ?elde. 255 When þai had sworn & ostage founde, Colbrond stirt vp in þat stounde: To fi?t he was ful felle. He was so michel & so vnrede, Þat non hors mi?t him lede, In gest as y ?ou telle. So mani he hadde of armes gere, Vnneþe a cart mi?t hem bere, Þe Inglisse for to quelle. Swiche armour as he hadde opon, Y-wis, no herd ?e neuer non, Bot as it ware a fende of helle. 256 Of mailes was nou?t his hauberk: It was al of anoþer werk, Þat meruail is to here. Alle it were þicke splentes of stiel, Þicke y-ioined strong & wel, To kepe þat fendes fere. Hossen he hadde also wele y-wrou?t: Oþer þan sp[l]entes was it nou?t Fram his fot to his swere. He was so michel & so strong, & þer-to so wonderliche long: In þe world was non his pere. 257 An helme he hadde on his heued sett, & þer-vnder a þicke bacinet. Unsemly was his wede. A targe he had wrou?t ful wel (Oþer metel was þer non on bot stiel), A michel & vnrede. Al his armour was blac as piche. Wel foule he was & loþliche, A grisely gom to fede. Þe hei?e king þat sitteþ on hei?e, Þat welt þis warld fer & nei?e, Made him wel iuel to spede. 258 A dart he bar in his hond kerueand, & his wepen about him stondand Boþe bihinde & biforn, Ax[e]s, & gisarmes scharp y-grounde, & glaiues for to ?iue wiþ wounde, To hundred & mo þer worn. Þe Inglis biheld him fast: King Aþelston was sore agast, Inglond he schuld haue lorn; For, when Gij sei?e þat wicked hert, He nas neuer so sore aferd Seþþen þat he was born. 259 Sir Gij lepe on his stede fot hot, & wiþ a spere, þat wele bot, To him he gan to ride. & he schet to Gij dartes þre: Of þe tvay þan failed he, Þe þridde he lete to him glide. Þurch Gyes scheld it glod & þurch his armour wiþouten abod Bitvene his arme & side, & quitelich into þe feld it ?ede Þe mountaunce of an acre brede Er þat it wald abide. 260 Sir Gij to him gan to driue, Þat his spere brast afiue On his scheld þat was so bounde. & Colbrond wiþ michel hete On Gyes helme he wald haue smite, & failed of him þat stounde: Bitvix þe sadel & þe arsoun Þe strok of þat feloun glod adoun Wiþouten wem or wounde, Þat sadel & hors atvo he smot, Into þe erþe wele half a fot, & Gij fel doun to grounde. 261 Sir Gij astite vp stirt As man þat was agremed in hert: His stede he hadde for-lore. On his helme he wald hit him þo, Ac he no mi?t nou?t reche þerto Bi to fot & ?ete more, Bot on his schulder þe swerd fel doun, & carf boþe plates & hauberioun Wiþ his grimli gore. Þurch al his armour stern & strong He made him a wounde a spanne long, Þat greued him ful sore. 262 Colbrond was sore aschame, & smot Gij wiþ michel grame: On his helm he hit him þo, Þat his floures euer-ichon & his gode charbukel ston Wel euen he carf atvo: Euen ato he smot his scheld, Þat it fley?e into þe feld. When Gij sey?e it was so, Þat he hadde his scheld forlorn, Half bihinde & half biforn, In hert him was wel wo. 263 & Gij hent his swerd an hond, & heteliche smot to Colbrond: As a child he stode him vnder. Opon þe scheld he ?aue him swiche a dent, Bifor þe stroke þe fiir out went, As it were li?t of þonder. Þe bondes of stiel he carf ichon, & in-to þe scheld a fot & half on Wiþ his swerd he smot asunder. & wiþ þe out-braiding his swerd brast: Þei Gij were þan sore agast It was litel wonder. 264 Þo was Gij sore desmayd, & in his hert wel iuel y-payd, For þe chaunce him was bifalle, & for he hadde lorn his gode brond & his stede opon þe sond. To our leuedi he gan calle. Þan gun þe Danis ost Ich puken oþer & make bost, & seyd among hem alle, ‘Now schal þe Inglis be slain in feld. Gret trouage Inglond schal ous ?eld, & euermore ben our þral.’ 265 ‘Now, sir kni?t,’ seyd Colbrond, ‘Þou hast lorn þi swerd in þine hond, Þi scheld, & eke þi stede. Do now wele, ?eld þe to me, & smertlich vnarme þe: Cri merci, y þe rede; &, for þou art so douhti kni?t, Þou durst o?ain me held fi?t, To mi lord y schal þe lede, & wiþ him þou schalt acorded be: In his court he wil hold þe, & finde þat þe is nede.’ 266 ‘Do way,’ seyd Gij, ‘þerof speke nou?t. Bi him þat al þis world haþ wrou?t, Ich hadde leuer þou were an-hong! Ac þou hast armes gret plente: Y-wis, þou most lene me On of þine axes strong.’ Colbrond swore bi Apolin, ‘Of al þe wepen þat is min Her schaltow non afong. Now þou wilt nou?t do bi mi rede, Þou schalt dye on iuel dede, Er þat it be ou?t long.’ 267 When Gij herd him speke so, Al sone he gan him turn þo, & to his wepen he geþ. Þer his axes stoden bi hem-selue, He kept on wiþ a wel gode helue, Þe best him þou?t he seþ. To Colbron[d] o?ain he ran, & seyd, ‘traitour,’ to him þan, ‘Þou schalt han iuel deþ. Now ich haue of þi wepen plente, Where-wiþ þat y may were me Ri?t maugre al þin teþ.’ 268 Colbrond þan wiþ michel hete On Gyes helme he wald haue smite Wiþ wel gret hert tene, Ac he failed of his dint, & þe swerd into þe erþe went A fot & more, y wene, & wiþ Colbrondes out-drau?t Sir Gij wiþ ax a strok him rau?t, A wounde þat was wele sene. So smertliche he smot to Colbrond, Þat his ri?t arme wiþ alle þe hond He strok of quite & clene. 269 When Colbrond feld him so smite, He was wel wroþ, ?e may wel wite: He gan his swerd vp fond, & in his left hond op it haf, & Gij in þe nek a strok him ?af As he [gan] stoupe for þe brond, Þat his heued fro þe bodi he smot, & into þe erþe half a fot: Þurch grace of godes sond Ded he feld þe glotoun þare. Þe Denis wiþ sorwe & care Þai di?t hem out of lond. 270 Bliþe were þe Inglis men ichon: Erls, barouns, & king Aþelston Þai toke sir Gij þat tide, & ladde him to Winchester toun Wiþ wel fair processioun Ouer al bi ich a side. For ioie belles þai gun ring, ‘Te deum laudamus’ þai gun sing, & play, & michel pride. Sir Gij vnarmed him, & was ful bliþe: His sclauain he axed also swiþe: No lenger he nold abide. 271 ‘Sir pilgrim,’ þan seyd þe king, ‘Whennes þou art, wiþouten lesing, Þou art douhti of dede; For þurch douhtines of þin hond Þou hast saued al Inglond: God quite þe þi mede, & mi treuþe y schal pli?t þe, So wele y schal feffe þe Boþe in lond & lede, Þat of riches in toun & tour Þou schalt be man of mest honour Þat woneþ in al mi þede.’ 272 ‘Sir king,’ seyd þe pilgrim, ‘Of alle þe lond þat is tin Y no kepe þerof na mare; Bot, now ichaue þe geant slain (Þerof, y-wis, icham ful fain), Mi way ichil forþ fare.’ ‘Merci, sir,’ þe king seyd þan, ‘Tel me, for him þat made man (For noþing þou ne spare), Tel me what þi name it be, Whennes þou art, & of what cuntre, Or y schal dye for care.’ 273 ‘Sir king,’ he seyd, ‘y schal tel it þe: What mi ri?t name it be Þou schalt witen anon, Ac þou schalt go wiþ me y-fere, Þat noman of our conseyl here, Bot þou & y alon.’ Þe king him graunted & was bliþe: He comand his folk al so swiþe No wi?t wiþ him to gon. Out of þe toun þan went he Wele half a mile fram þat cite, & þer made Gij his mon. 274 ‘Sir king,’ seyd Gij, ‘vnderstond to me: O þing y schal now pray þe, Astow art curteys and hende, ?if y mi name schal þe sayn, Þat to noman þou no schalt me wrayn, To þis ?ere com to þende. Gij of Warwike mi nam is ri?t: Whilom y was þine owhen kni?t, & held me for þi frende; & now icham swiche astow may see. God of heuen biteche y þe: Mi way y wil forþ wende.’ 275 When þe king sei?e, sikerly, Þat it was þe gode Gij Þat fro him wald his way, On knes he fel adoun to grounde: ‘Leue sir Gij,’ in þat stounde, ‘Merci,’ he gan to say. ‘For godes loue, bi-leue wiþ me, & mi treuthe y schal pli?t þe, Þat y schal þis day Sese & ?iue in-to þine hond Half þe reme of Inglond. For godes loue, say nou?t nay.’ 276 ‘Sir king,’ seyd Gij, ‘y nil nou?t so. Haue þou þi lond for euer-mo, & god y þe bi-teche. Ac, ?if Herhaud to þis lond com, & bring wiþ him Reynbroun, mi sone, Help him, y þe biseche; For þai er boþe hende & fre. On Herhaud þou mi?t trust þe To take of þine fon wreche.’ Þai kisten hem togider þo: Al wepeand þai wenten ato Wiþouten ani more speche. 277 Þe king wel sore wepe for pite, & went him hom to his meyne Wiþ a mournand chere. His folk o?aines him gan gon, & asked þe king sone anon What man þe pilgrim were. Þai seyd, ‘he is a douhti kni?t: Wald Iesu ful of mi?t He wald leue wiþ ous here.’ Þe king seyd, ‘al stille ?e be: What he is ?our non schal wite for me, I-wis, of al þis ?ere.’ 278 Sir Gij went in his way forþ ri?t, Oft he þonked god almi?t Þat þe geaunt was slawe. To Warwike he went, to þat cite Þer he was lord of þat cuntre To hold wiþ ri?t lawe. He nas knowen þer of no man, When he to þe castel ?ates cam: Þerof he was ful fawe. Among þe pouer men he him dede Þer þai weren vp in a stede, & sett him on a rawe. 279 & Feliis þe countas was þer þan: In þis warld was non better wiman, In gest as-so we rede; For þritten pouer men & ?ete mo For hir lordes loue sche loued so Ich day sche gan fede, Wiþ þan god & our leuedi Schuld saue hir lord sir Gij, & help him at his nede. Sche no stint noiþer day no ni?t, For him sche bisou?t god almi?t Wiþ bedes & almos dede. 280 On a day þe leuedi went to mete, & bad men schuld biforn hir fete Hir pouer men al biden, & men brou?t hem euerichon, & Gij of Warwike was þat on Of þo ich þritten. In his hert he hadde gret care, Þat he schuld be knawen þare Of hem þat hadde him sen, Ac þer was non so wise of si?t Þat him þer knowe mi?t: So misais he was & lene. 281 Þe leuedi biheld him inliche, Hou mesays he was, sikerliche. Curteys sche was & hende: Of euerich mete, of euerich d[r]ing Þat sche ete of herself, wiþouten lesing, Sche was him ful mende; Of hir bere & of hir wine In hir gold coupe afine Oft sche gan him sende, & bad him ich day com he schold: Mete & drink sche finde him wold Vnto his liues ende. 282 Sir [Gij] þonked þat leuedi oft, Bot alle anoþer was his þou?t Þan he wald to hir say. When þe grace were y-seyd, & þe bordes adoun layd, Out of toun he went his way. Into a forest wenden he gan To an hermite he knewe er þan, To speke him ?if he may. &, when he þider comen was, Þe gode hermite þurch godes grace Was dede & loken in clay. 283 Þan þou?t sir Gij anon Þat wald he neuer þennes gon Þer whiles he war oliue. Wiþ a prest he spac of þat cuntray Þat dede him seruise ich day, & of his sinnes gan schriue. Wiþ him he hadde þer a page Þat serued him in þat hermitage Wiþouten chest & striue. No lenger was he liues þere Bot ni?en moneþes of a ?ere, As ?e may listen & liþe. 284 In slepe as Gij lay ani?t, God sent an angel bri?t Fram heuen to him þare. ‘Gij,’ seyd þe angel, ‘slepestow? Hider me sent þe king Iesu To bid þe make þe ?are; For bi þe ei?tenday at morwe He schal deliuer þe out of þi sorwe, Out of þis warld to fare. To heuen þou schalt com him to, & liue wiþ ous euer-mo In ioie wiþouten care.’ 285 When Gij was waked of þat drem, Of an angel he sei?e a glem: ‘What artow?’ þan seyd he. Þe angel answerd, ‘fram heuen y cam: Mi?hel is mi ri?t nam. God sent me to þe To bid þe make þe redi way: Bi þe ei?tenday þou schalt day, Wel siker mau?tow be. & y schal feche þi soule ful euen, & bere it to þe þlis of heuen Wiþ grete solempnete.’ 286 Þe angel goþ forþ, & Gij bileft stille: His bedes he bad wiþ gode wille To Iesu heuen king, & when his term was nere gon His knaue he cleped to him anon, & seyd, wiþouten lesing, ‘Sone,’ he seyd, ‘y pray now þe, Go to Warwike þat cite Wiþ-outen more duelling, & when þou comest þer, y þe biseche, Gret wele þe countas wiþ þi speche, & take hir þis gold ring. 287 & say þe pilgrim hat hir biforn, Þat hir mete was to born, On þe pouer mannes rawe, Gret hir wele in al þing, & sende to hir þis gold ring, ?if þat sche wil it knawe. Als son as sche haþ þer-of a si?t, Sche wil it knawe anon ri?t, & be þerof ful fawe. Þan wil sche ax ware y be: Leue sone, for loue of me Þe soþe to hir þou schawe, 288 & say icham for godes loue In þe forest hermite bicome, Mine sinnes for to bete, & bid hir for þe loue of me Þat sche com hider wiþ þe: For no þing sche no lete. & when ?e com ?e finde me dede: Do me neuer hennes lede, Bot graue me here in grete. & after sche schal dye, y-wis, & com to me in-to heuen blis, Þer ioies her ful swete.’ 289 Þe knaue went forþ anon, In-to Warwike he gan gon Bifor þat leuedi fre, &, when he hadde þat leuedi founde, On knes he fel adoun to grounde, & seyd, ‘listen to me: Þe pilgrim þat ete þe biforn, Þat þi mete was to born, An hermite now is he. He greteþ þe wele in al þing, & sent þe þis gold ring In sum tokening to be.’ 290 Þe leuedi tok þat ring anhond, & loked þeron & gan wiþstond, Þe letters for to rede. ‘Ow, certes,’ quaþ þe leuedi, ‘Þis ring y ?af mi lord sir Gij, When he fro me ?ede.’ For sorwe sche fel aswon, y-wis, & when þat sche arisen is To þe knaue sche gan spede. ‘Leue sone,’ sche seyd, ‘y pray þe, Wher is þat pilgrim? telle þou me, & gold schal be þi mede.’ 291 ‘Madame,’ seyd þe knaue ful skete, ‘In þe forest ichim lete: Ri?t now y com him fro. He is ner ded in þe hermitage: On his halue y make þe message; Y-wis, he bad me so, & bad þou schust to him come For þat ich trewe loue Þat was bitvene ?ou tvo. Do him neuer lede oway, Bot biri him ri?t þer in clay. Oliue sestow him no mo.’ 292 Þe leuedi was glad of þat tiding, & þonked Iesu heuen king, & was in hert ful bliþe Þat sche schuld sen hir lord sir Gij; Ac for o þing sche was sori, Þat he schuld dye so swiþe. Þai made hem redi for to wende Wiþ kni?tes & wiþ leuedis hende: On a mule þai sett hir siþe, & wiþ al þe best of þat cite To þermitage went sche, As ?e may listen & liþe. 293 To þermitage when þai com, Þer þai li?t al & some, & in sche went wel euen. When þat sche sei?e hir lord sir Gij, Sche wept & made doleful cri Wiþ a ful reweful steuen. Sir Gij loked on hir þare: His soule fram þe bodi gan fare. A þousand angels & seuen Vnder-fenge þe soule of Gij, & bar it wiþ gret molodi Into þe blis of heuen. 294 Þan was þat leuedi ful of care, For hir lord was fram hir fare: ‘Allas’ it was hir song. Sche kist his mouþe, his chin also, & wepe wiþ hir ei?en to, & hir hondes sche wrong. Gret honour dede our lord for Gij: A swete braþe com fram his bodi, Þat last þat day so long, Þat in þis world spices alle No mi?t cast a swetter smalle As þen was hem among. 295 Þe leudy astite dede send hir sond After bischopes, abotes of þe lond, Þe best þat mi?t be founde, &, when þider was com þat fair ferred, To Warwike þai wald him lede, As lord of michel mounde. Bot al þe folk þat þer was No mi?t him stir of þat plas Þer he lay on þe grounde. An hundred men about him were, No mi?t him nou?t þennes bere For heuihed þat stounde. 296 Þan seyd þe leuedi, ‘lete him be stille, Neuer more remoun him y nille, No do him hennes lede. He sent me bode wiþ his page To biri him in þis hermitage Simpliche wiþouten prede.’ Þay tok a þrou? of marbel ston, & leyd his bodi þer-in anon Atird in kni?tes wede. Fair seruise þan was þare Of bischopes, abbotes þat þer ware, & clerkes to sing & rede. 297 When þai hadde birid his bodi, anon Þe gret lordinges euerichon Hom þai gun wende, Ac þe leuedi left stille þare: Sche nold neuer þennes fare; Sche kidde þat sche was kende. Sche liued no lenger, soþe to say, Bot ri?t on þe fiftenday Sche dyed þat leuedi hende, & was birid hir lord by; & now þai er togider in compeynie In ioie þat neuer schal ende. 298 When sir Tirri herd telle þis, Þat Gij, his fere, ded is, & birid in þe clay, He com to þis lond, wiþ-outen lesing, & bisou?t Aþelston þe king His bodi to leden oway. He it graunted him ful ?are, Into Lorain wiþ him gan fare, Into his owhen cuntray. An abbay he lete make þo For to sing for hem to Euermore til domesday. 299 Now haue ?e herd, lordinges, of Gij, Þat in his time was so hardi, & holden hende & fre, & euer he loued treuþe & ri?t, & serued god wiþ al his mi?t, Þat sit in trinite, & þer-fore at his ending day He went to þe ioie þat lasteþ ay, & euer-more schal be. Now god leue ous to liue so, Þat we may þat ioie com to. Amen, par charite. Explicit. Reinbrun, Gij sone of Warwike. 1 Iesu, þat ert of mi?te most, Fader, & sone, & holy gost, Ich bidde þe a bone: Ase þow ert lord of our ginning, & madest heuene and alle þing, Se, and sonne, and mone, ?eue hem grace wel to spede Þat herkneþ what y schel rede, Iesu, god in trone. Of a kni?t was to batayle boun, Sire Gij is sone, þat hi?te Rey[n]broun, Of him y make my mone. 2 His fader Gij, þat him get, He was a werrour swiþe gret: Þar nas nowhar his per In Fraunce, in Pycardy, In Spayne, in Lombardy, Neyþer fer ne ner. Mani batayle he be-gan For þe loue of o wimman Þat was him lef & dere. Siþe Rey[n]broun on hire he wan, Þat was a swiþe dou?ti man, Ase ?e may forþward here. 3 Þay were togedre fifti ni?t, After a spusede þat swete wi?t Wiþ meche melody. Þanne was be-?ete þat baroun, His sone þat was cleped Rey[n]broun, Of þat kni?t sire Gij. Fourti wikes wiþ child ?he was & dilyured þour? [godes] gras And is moder Mari. Cristned hit was werschipliche: Reinbroun men calde him, sikerliche, For-soþe and nou?t ne lye. 4 Heraud hadde þat child to lore Seue winter and wel more: Ful wel he gan him lere. Be þat he was seue winter old, He was a fair child and a bold, And of swete chere. So hit befel þat of fer lond Marchauns riche, ich vnder-stond, Hider þai come were: Gold and seluer þai brou?te meche, Badekenes and pane riche, Gris and menyuer, 5 Bras, maslyn, yren, & stel, Wod-wex, selk, and cendel, Gingiuer and galingale, Clowes, quibibes, gren de Paris, Pyper, and comyn, and swet anis, Mani a riche bale, Fykes, reisyn, dates, Almaund, rys, pomme-garnates, Kanel and setewale, Scarlet and grene wel y-wrou?t: More richesse wiþ hem hii brou?t Þan y can tellen in tale. 6 Þai riuede at Londen þat cite: King Aþelstond þan fonden he, Þat her was king wiþ croune. A ?af hem leue in alle wise To wende wiþ her marchaundise In is londe fro toun to toune. To Walingforde þai gonne fare: A strong bour? þai fonde þare (Þai boskede & made hem boune), Ac it was strued, wiþ-outen lesing, For werre of Heraud & þe king: Hit was ni? brou?t adoun. 7 Þe marchauns kedde hii wer fre: A Spayniis mvle than token he, To Heraud hii [hit] sende. For he was lord of þat cite, Wiþ him hii þou?te wel to be: So þai han him kende. Sire Heraud, for soþ to say, Bad hem ete wiþ him þat day, Er hij þannes wende. Þe marchauns seie þe child goand In þe halle faire pleiande, Þat was so faire and hende. 8 At a kni?t hii askede anon ri?t Whas was þo child so faire of si?t And of swete chere, And he answerde anon, y pli?t, ‘Hit is Gij is sone, þe gode kni?t, Þat Heraud haþ to lere.’ Þe marchauns hem beþou?te, ?if hii þat child haue mou?te, Hii wolde stele him þere; &, ?if hii hadde þat child bolde, Richely in-to her londe þai wolde, And selle hit full dere. 9 Wiþ þe porter þai speke stille, Þat hii hadden al her wille. Þai ?eue him riche mede: He betau?te hem þe child þare, And into schip þai gonne fare; Away þai gonne him lede. Þay gonne saily toward Roussy: Al glad hii were þet londe to sy; Hii þou?te wel to spede. Al siker hii were alond te gon, Ac swiche a strom hem cam upon, Þat sore hem gonne drede. 10 Þe wind began to blowen loude, Þe elmence þikkede on þe cloude: Gret strom hem wex vpon. Þe four wyndes began to blowe, Þe se gan tornen & to þrowe: Ded hii wende haue ben echon. Here ropes to-borsten, her mast also: Þar nas non þat him nas wo; Hii made reuful mon. To Iesu Crist þai gonne crye And to his moder Marie: Nas þer no beter won. 11 Þe wind faire slake gan: Mery in þe se þe schip ran. Ase god hit wolde Þai wer driuen al þe ni?t: In Aufrik þai riuede ri?t; Þai toke a wel gode holde. Þe marchauns han it vnder-nome, Þat hii beþ into Aufrik come: Hii þou?te þat hii wolde Þe king of þe lond presenti Wiþ þat child þat was so fry And of chere bolde. 12 Of hem hii token marchauns þre Þat noble were, curteis, & fre, Wiþoute more duelling: Þai toke þat child, veraiment, And made þerwiþ a present To Arguus þe king. Þe king hadde a dou?ter fair: Of al Aufrik ?he was air, A swiþe fair ?onling. Meche ?he kouþe of menstralcie, Of harpe, of fiþele, of sautri, Of romaunce reding. 13 So was Reynbroun, for soþ to say, Meche liche þat faire may Of semlaunt and of chere. Besou?t ?he haþ be hir moder rede, & to hire fader king ?he sede, ‘Leue, fader dere, Y mote him in me chaumber norsy: ?et a may me seruy; Norture y schel him lere.’ Þe king him graunted þour? alle þing, For he hire louede wiþ-oute lesing, To ben hire plaie-fere. 14 Whan sire Heraud parseued was Þe child was stole, for þat cas Gret sorwe he gan make. He let seche him in þat cite: Mani man made gret pite For þat childes sake. Wiþ mesagers a sente is sonde To seche him in mani londe ?if hii him mi?te of-take; &, whan hii him finde ne mi?te, Sorwe hii made day & ni?te: For drede þai gonne quake. 15 Hit nas nou?t longe after þan, Þat in Londen held king Aþelstan A riel parlement. Sire Heraud þeder gan gon: Þe king a werschipede & mani on, Whan he was þeder y-went. Oþer hadde þer-of envie, And þou?te hii wolde on him lye, Þat a wer y-schent, & segge he hadde Reinbroun sold For is wi?te of rede gold To þe marchauns, verayment. 16 ‘Lordinges,’ seide þe king y-core, ‘Al ?e ben to me y-swore For helpe me at nede. ?our consaile wite y welle. Wel ?e witen ?e han herd telle Ase ?our eldren sede, Þat þe king of Denemark Þour? a geaunt stor & stark Kalaungeþ al oure þede. A gret ost he haþ y-nome & ?if he may vs ouercome He makeþ our sides blede.’ 17 ‘Sire,’ queþ Heraud, ‘þarf þe no drede: Þour? godes help we scholle wel spede Þei he vs wile asaile. Gode kni?tes ?e han & cite stro[n]g: ?if ?e him douteþ it is wrong For al is grete taile. Myn eldren seide, ich vnder-stonde, Þe Dennisch men hadde ri?t in þis londe, Wiþ-outen eni faile, Whilom, & nou?t ful ?ore it is, & siþþe þai han it lore, y-wis, And here folk in bataile. 18 Now þai han loren here ri?t: Hii weren ouercomen in fi?t Þour? help of god almi?te. Þarfore ensemle þe barouns Þat haþ þe toures & þe tounes Before þe an hi?te. At what hauen þai alende, Ase tit a?en hem we scholle wende Wiþ hors and armes bri?te. & ?if a comeþ in þis londe, y-wis, We scholle sle him & alle his: So wel we scholle fi?te.’ 19 Þanne seide þe king, ‘þow hast wel sed: Þou hast red me a gode red; Y-blessed mote þow be. A beter rede ne wot y non: Ase þow hast seid so y schel don, Also mote ich þe. Þow ert me beste consailer: In al þis lond þer nis þe per Þat ich mowe y-se. Al þe while icham coren king, Don ich wile be þe teching, Sire Heraud þe fre.’ 20 Þe duk Medyok vp aras: Of al Cornewaile lord he was, A sterne kni?t & a grim. ‘Sire king,’ a seide, ‘herkne to me. Þow ert nou?t wis ase þe holdest þe, Whan þow leuest on him. Þow werschepest him fer & ner, And he nis boute a losenger Ful of tresoun [and] gin. Beter we beþ to þe consaile Þanne þe treitour, wiþ-outen faile, Be god and seinte Martyn. 21 His gode lord traye he gan Þat þour? him he was maked man, Of Warwik sire Gij: Euel he haþ is while ?olde, Whan he Reinbroun, is sone, solde To þe marchauns of Roussy: For gold & seluer gret plente To þe marchauns diliurede he, Ase we gonne aspie. & ?if he hadde þe ri?te lawe A scholde ben hanged & drawe For þat trecherie.’ 22 Þo Heraud herde him speke so, Him þou?te his herte barst ato: Vp he sterte an hye. ‘Felawe duk,’ a seide, ‘þow lyxst, Whan þow wiþ tresoun me betwyxst: Þow dost me vileynie. Þow hit schelt to soþe bringe Þat þow hast seid be-fore þe kinge, Or þow schelt abye. Hasteliche now arme þe: Anon it schel proued be, Þat þow dost on me lye. 23 Ich wile þat y ben hanged & drawe Boute y defende me wiþ þe lawe Of þis famacioun, Þat þow seist y scholde selle Me lordes sone þat ich of telle, Þat men clepede Reinbroun. Whan ich þe soþe parseued hadde, Þe marchauns him hadde wei ladde Me of-þou?te þat tresoun.
