Wiþ mesagers y sente me sonde To seche him in mani londe: Þow lyxst on me, feloun. 24 Before þe king i say þe ri?t, Þar-to me treuþe y þe pli?t: To seche him y schel fonde In Fraunce, in Lombardie, In Spayne, in Spir, in Roussie, In mani an honkouþ londe. Betwene þis and þe lond of Ynde ?if a be, y schel him fynde, And bringe him to honde. & whan ichaue so y-do Þin heued y schel smite þe fro: For no man nel ich wonde.’ 25 ‘Pes, feloun,’ queþ [þ]erl of Cornewayle, ‘Al þe lesing schel þe nou?t vaile: Traytour þow worst holde.’ Þat herde anoþer kni?t: Egar a het, forsoþ apli?t, Heraud is man y-tolde. His steward, for-soþ, he was: He sterte vp in þat plas, And to the duk a wolde. ‘Felawe duk,‘ a seide, ‘þow lixst, Whan þow me lorde be-twixst Þat he Reinbroun solde. 26 Fif hondred siþe haue þow maugre Of Iesu, þat sit in trinite, Iesu ful of mi?t, Boute þow swiþe arme þe, & do þe bataile a?enes me, And proue it ari?t.’ Þar hii hadde togedres smite, Nadde þe king hit vnder-?ite, & departede hem an hi?t. He bad hem lete be þat fare, & besou?te hem to make hem ?are A?enes þe Dennisch king to fi?t. 27 Heraud wiþ is ferde fre Wente to Walingford þat cite Ful of sorwe and care. ‘Egar,’ a seide, ‘þow schelt be-leue, & kepe þis land to me be-heue, And forþ ich wile fare, Til ich Reynbroun finde may: Y ne schel reste ni?t ne day, Til ich wite whar he ware. Ac war þe fro þerl of Cornewayle: He wile arere on þe batayle; He nele þe noþing spare.’ 28 ‘Sire,’ queþ Egar, ‘we scholle vs were, Þat he ne schel vs noþing dere, Þei he vs wile agreue.’ Heraud went out of þat cite: For him was maked gret pite, Whan he tok his leue. Hasteliche to schip a wente, Gode wind and weder god him sente: In Denemark þai gonne riue. In Fraunce, in Lombardie, In Spayne, in Spyr, in Roussie Reynbroun a sou?te bliue. 29 Þour? mani londes þai him sou?te: Whan hii mi?te finde nou?te, To schip þai gonne fare. To Costantin noble hii wolde wende: Swiche a tempest god hem gan sende, Þat hii come nou?t þare. Þai were driue wiþ-oute þe toun: In Aufrik þai riuede soune. Þanne wer þai ful of care. Þe cite on þe riuage hii sye, Meche & wide, & walles hye: Of blisse þai wer al bare. 30 ‘O god,’ seide þe meister þo, ‘Gret mishap is come vs to: Our lif y telle y-lore. In Aufrik we ben, wiþ-outen lesing, Upon Arguus lond þe king: Worsse man nas neuer bore. Al þat leueþ in godes lawe A wile hem hongen & to-drawe: His oþ he haþ y-swore. Al for-soþe, we beþ dede, Boute god vs helpe at our nede, Þat was of Marie bore.’ 31 Heraud seide, ‘whas is þis cite? Distrued it is, so þenkeþ me: Her haþ be strong bataile.’ Þe maroner seide, ‘y þe telle For soþe, sire, lye i nelle: Wiþouten eni faile, Hit is þemerailes Parsan: In þis world nis þer worsse man Cristene men to asaile.’ Þe Sarazins come wiþ þis, & nemeþ Heraud & alle his, And distrueþ is vitaile. 32 Þai nomen Heraud & al is man, And brou?te hem before Parsan, Þat was of gret power. He let hem caste in prisoun Stinkande & þerk, wel fer adoun, For þai cristen were. Lite þai ete & dronke, ywis: Vnneþe her lif sostened is; To god he made his prayere. For Reynbroun him was ful wo, For he neste whider he was go: He made reuly chere. 33 ‘O,’ seide [he], ‘allas, allas! In werre dou?ti man y was, And now icham for-lore.’ On of þe gaylers herde þis: To þemeraile a wente, y-wis, And gan him telle fore: ‘Sire,’ a seide, ‘wite nou?t ?e Of a prisoun ?e han in ?our pouste, A noble man y-kore? A is wel dou?ti in bataile Ase icham to ?ou swore.’ 34 Queþ þemeraile, ‘bringe him forþ now. ?if he be swich ase seistow, Meche helpe me a mi?te.’ Þe gayler wente a?en anon, & to þe prisoun he gan gon, And Heraud vp atwi?te. In a sklauin he gan him folde. Swiþe meche a was be-holde Of mani a dou?ti kni?te. His berde was to is brest y-wax, To his gerder heng is fax: Grisliche he was of si?te. 35 Before þemeraile hii gan him lede, & a-reisoned him in ech a side, ‘Man, what is þe name? Whar wer þow bore (tel me now), Þat so meche of werre canstow? Of þe ichaue game. Ich, ameraile Parsan, Icham a swiþe dou?ti man: Wide springeþ me fame. Mi?te [y] of þe siker be, Þat þou woldest serue me, Ne schostow haue no schame.’ 36 He answerde, ‘leue lord, To þe ich wile bere rekord, And telle y wile þe: Heraud, for-soþ, me nam is (In grete dede ichaue be er þis), So men clepeþ me. ?if me stringþe wer a?en i-come Þat ichaue lore in þe prisone, Ich wer of gret pouste. Find me stede gode & li?t, Spere, & scheld, & armes bri?t: Þe man wile ich be.’ 37 Queþ þemeraile, ‘wolcome, ywis! Þow schelt haue þat þe nede is, Bri?t armur & stede. Ingliis þow ert, sikerly: Knew þow ou?t þe gode Gij, Þat dou?ti wes of dede?’ Heraud seide, ‘y knew him wel: His man icham & euer be schel. He was tau?t me to fede. His sone was stolen him fro: To seche him icham y-go, ?if god me wolde spede.’ 38 Þemeraile cleped is chaumborlain, And bad him wiþ al is mayn Heraud to him take. In pourpre pal þei gan him schrede, & founde him al þat was nede, And baþes let him make. On a day sire ameraile Tok Heraud in consaile Wiþ-oute þe castel gate: ‘Now Arguus king werreþ on me, Me nis leued boute þis cite For grete werre & hate. 39 Þe king haþ a kni?t wiþ him Sterne in bataile & swiþe grim: Of swich þow neuer herd. In þis world nis man, sikerly, Boute hit wer þe lord sire Gij, Þat of him nolde ben aferd. Mi?test of him awreke me, A noble prins þan schostow be, & sle him wiþ dent of swerd.’ Heraud seide, ‘so y schel do, ?if god wile helpe me þerto, Be min hore berd.’ 40 Wiþ þat com a mesagere bold, To þemeraile he haþ y-told Swiþe hard tiding: King Arguus stiward wiþ-outen let On of is castels hadde be-set, Wiþouten eni lesing. Whan þemeraile herde þis, He bad is stiward, for-soþ y-wis, His folk be-fore him bringe. So a dede ri?t anon, & bad hem bosken euerichon Al boun to batailinge. 41 Heraud lep on a rabyte Þat was meche, & noþing lite, Rod out of þe toun. Þat ost him siwede fair & wel, Til hii come to þe castel Wiþ spere and gounfanoun, Wiþ helm on heued & brinie bri?t. Iyren-wrye mani a kni?t To bataile wer þai boun. Ayþer ost gan oþer asaile: Ech man fondede, wiþouten faile, To felle is foman adoun. 42 Heraud a Sarazin smot, Þat he fel doun fot hot Dede of is stede. Þe þredde, þe ferþe þat he mai hitte— No man mi?te his strok wiþ-sitte. For wreþþe a wolde a-wede. Wiþ is swerd of meche pris Mani Sarazin a slou?, y-wis, And made here sides blede. Þe Sarazins seide hit was a fend Þe deuel hadde þeder i-sent Þemeraile to spede. 43 Þe king hadde a Sarazin, His stiward, þat seruede Apolyn: Heraud he gan þrete. Heraud he mete & is men echon: Hard þai hewe to-gedre anon, And delde dentes grete. Þe stiward was sconfited þere, Abated was þe meister banere: To fle þai nolde lete. Heraud siwede him on a rabyte: Hard hii gonne to-gedre smite Sterne strokes and grete. 44 Here scheftes schiurede, scheldes flitte, Brenyes barsten, hauberk ritte: Þar was strong bataile. Heraud ouercom him in þat fi?t, And ladde him to his folk ari?t, Wiþouten eni faile. Prisouns þai toke gret plente: Forþ hii wente to þat cite To þemeraile, & presente him þe stiward, Þat in werre was so hard, Swiþe he? of paraile. 45 Þanne seide þemeraile, ‘Heraud, do be me consaile: Me stiward þow schelt be. Erles, barouns, riche & poure, Al me land folk lasse & more Scholle do after þe.’ Þanne gret werre he began: Boþe into is hond he wan Castel and cite Þat þemeraile hadde lore: King Arguus made þar-fore Deul and gret pite. 46 Þo þe king wiste þis, Þat his stiward nomen is, And al his men a-slawe, Wroþ he was and sori: His barouns a clepede an hie, And tolde to hem þat sawe. Þanne answerde an old kni?t, ‘Sire, y nel þe lye no-wi?t: A kni?t of cristene lawe Þemeraile is souder is he. Þe wer beter þan þis cite Þat he wer of dawe. 47 Hore a is and kni?t ful eld: Wel gode hit were to flen is scheld. Sire, þe mi?t me leue: In al þe lond Sarazin þer nis Wer he neuer so strong, y-wis, Þat he nolde to-cleue.’ Þe king seide, ‘a fend it is. To Mahoun i swore, y-wis, Wel sore y schel him greue. Min ost schel ensembled be, In is lond schel brenne and sle: No cite schel ich be-leue.’ 48 Þe king a parlement let crie. To þemeraile a wolde an hie Wiþ bri?t armvr & stede, His castels struede & is cite: Þat Heraud wan þanne les he, Dou?ti man of dede. Whan þemeraile wiste þis He bed is kni?tes, for-soþ y-wis, To helpe him at is nede. Heraud was prest to bataile: Þe king is ost he gan asaile; God þat day him spede! 49 Faste þei smite to her fon: Wiþ swerdes, speres wel gode won Togedres þai gonne fi?te. Gret slau?ter was in eiþer side: Þe blod ran in þe feld wel wide Of mani a dou?ti kni?te. Heraud mette wiþ þe king, & smot him wiþ is swerd keruing A strok of meche mi?te: Þer he hadde slawe him þo, Boute his ost com him to: An hors þai gonne him di?te. 50 Wel stoutliche þe king gan fi?te: Al þat a mette he felde doun ri?te. Heraud he gan discrie. Þemeraile was sconfited þere: Abated was þe meister banere And al here cheualrie. In eche side asailed a is Wiþ speres & wiþ swerdes, iwis, Þat he mi?te nou?t flie. Wiþ is swerd a wereþ him wel In eche side, ase a gode kni?t schel, Whiles a mi?te dri?e. 51 Þo he se? Heraud a cleped him to: To helpe him he gan go. An erl Heraud gan mete: Heraud wiþ is fauchoun him smot A dent þat þour? is helm bot; Þar a lefte þe swete. Heraud & þemeraile anon Delde dentes wel god won: For noþing þai nolde lete. Þe king þai sailede and al is men: So mani ?ede to deþe þen, Þat grimly þai gonne grete. 52 Þe king wel sori þanne was he, Whan he se? is men fle, And al y-brou?t to gronde. Whar þat he se? Heraud ride He fle? awei be þat oþer side Wel sory in þat stonde. His men ouercome were: Þar-fore sori he was þere & for his owene wonde. King Arguus, for-soþ, a geþ: A was afered of is deþ ?if þat a were y-fonde. 53 Whan Heraud parseued is, Be his armes a knew him, iwis, And after him he gan ride. Ne? he hadde him ouer-come, Slawe, oþer in þe feld y-nome In þat ilche tide. Þanne se? he come a ?ingling (Ouer al þe oþer a mi?te be king) Out of þe wodes side. Þe king him hadde dobbed kni?t, ?eue him hors & armes bri?t Wiþ wel meche pride. 54 Whan he se? þe king fleande, Heraud after him folwande, He him gan discrie: ‘Old man, no forþer þow ne gon, Boute þe ?eue me bataile anon. Þow dost a gret folye. Þe lif þow lest er þe gon: Þin heued þe king schel haue anon; For-soþ, þow schelt abye. Þe rabite is min, sikerliche: Y ne disirede neuer hors so meche Þat y sau? wiþ eye.’ 55 Sire Heraud knew him anon Be his armes he hadde vpon: Togedres þai gonne ride, Þat boþe þei fellen of here stede, & seþe gonne swerdes brede: No lenger þai nolde abide. Hii cleueþ helm & scheldes bo: Gret fi?t þer was betwene hem to In þat ilche tide. Þai hewe þe scheldes of gode entaile, Þe hauberk of so gode a maile Te-borsten be boþe side. 56 Betwene hem was strong batayle: Eiþer fondede, wiþouten faile, To bringe oþer to dede. Ac, ?if aiþer wiste of oþer ari?t, Betwene hem to þar ner no fi?t For none skines nede. Sire Heraud drou? him an he?, And seide, ‘kni?t corteis and sle?, Alse god þe spede, What is þe name? tel þow me, For godes loue in trinite, And of what þede. 57 A?ild þe now to me: Gret harm it wer to sle þe, So ?ong a bacheler; For neuer kni?t y ne fond So wel werchande wiþ dent of brond Naiþer fer ne ner.’ Reinbroun seide, ‘þerof be stille: Þat telle þe y ne wille, Be godes moder dere. Er þan ich wile ?elde me Erst þin heued schel of fle Faste, be þe swere. 58 Boute þow now telle me Wheþen þow ert, & what þow be, I schel þe sle anon ri?t; For þow ert old & whit i-blowe, Þe stringþe is gon alse y trowe, Þe power and þe mi?t.’ Heraud seide, ‘me frend fre, So fareþ folk in me contre In bataile and in fi?t: Whan hii ginneþ for to helde, Þanne þai wexeþ stout, & belde, And stronge men, apli?t. 59 Er þow fro me departed be, Wel ?onge thow schelt holde me, And dou?ti man of dede.’ Togedres þai smite, wiþ-outen faile, Ase sterne lyouns in bataile, Kni?tes stif on stede. To-gedre þai smite ernest & faste: Þe fur out of here helmes braste, And made here sides blede. Ful dedli fon now þai are: ?et þai scholle be frendes þare; Crist þer-to hem spede! 60 Heraud seide, ‘sire kni?t, Herkne to me a lite wi?t, For þe courteisie. Gode þow ert & hardi, ywis: In al þis land þe beter nis Þat ich conne aspie. ?if it were þe y-teld Which ichaue ben in feld Of mi?t and of meistrie, Ne wostow neuer aschamed be Þe name for to telle me, Ne holde hit to vileynie.’ 61 ‘Sire olde man,’ þanne seide he, ‘For a coward ich holde þe. Min armes beþ al sonde, Me strokes beþ sene on þin helm cler: Out of þe scheld ichaue a quarter Y-feld to þe grounde.’ Heraud seide, ‘me frend fre, Þei min armes apeired be, Me bodi naþ no wounde. What is þe name? tel me fore, & y schel sai þe whar ich was bore, Er ich fro þe founde. 62 Swiche tiding þow mi?t of me here, Or ich of þe in swiche manere, Þat frendes scholle we be. I ne aske it for no vileinie, Boute for meche courteisie: For loue ich asked þe.’ Wiþ þat Reynbroun wiþ-drou? him þere: Wiþ drery semlaunt & reuful chere To Heraud seide he: ‘Kni?t,’ a seide, ‘thow ert wise, Sle?, and hardi, of gret prise, Be god in trinite. 63 Y nolde haue told it for non awe: Erst ich wolde ben islawe In þis ilche batayle. In Ingelond ich was y-bore, So were min eldren me be-fore, Wiþouten eni faile. Gij a Warwik me fader was: No beter kni?t neuer nas, Ase wid ase man mai saile. A stiward hadde me fader Gioun Þat hi?te Heraud, þe noble baroun, Swiþe hi? of paraile. 64 Lord he was of al Arderne: Ich was take him to lerne To conne of courteisie, And siþe marchaundes stele me (And brou?te me to þis contre) Þat weren of Russie. Þe king me haþ dobbed kni?t, & ?eue me hors & armes bri?t To lede is chiualrie. Be me lai a dede me swere In eueri bataile is baner to bere: Þar-of y nou?t ne lie.’ 65 Whan Heraud herde þis, Þat he Gij is sone is, Away a cast is scheld. ‘Lord,’ a seide, ‘in trinite, Fader and sone, y-herd þow be! Þis dai y bide in min eld, Þat ich me lordes sone se may!’ For ioie a wep al þe day, And swonede in þe feld. Reinbroun hadde of him pite, And seide, ‘sire kni?t, tel what þe be, For god, þat alle þing weld.’ 66 ‘Heraud,’ a seide, ‘me name is: ‘Ich norschede þe, Reinbroun, y-wis; In my nory þow were.’ Sone Reinbroun wiste þis, Þat [he] Heraud of Arderne is, Merci a cride him þere. Sire Heraud tok him vp þo Leuelich in is armes to Wiþ hertte & wel gode chere. On here stedes lopen he, & forþ hii ride to þe cite Wiþ meche ioie y-fere. 67 To þemeraile tolden he How þai acorded be Þour? grace of god almi?te. King Arguus was ouer-come, & al is men y-slawe and nome In þat ilche fi?te. Heraud & Reinbroun toke leue þo Into Ingelond for to go, And in-to schip hem di?te. So longe hii sailede in þe se, Þat in a lond thanne riuede he Þat wonder was of si?te. 68 Hii ne seie castel ne cite: Erst hii wente in al þe contre (So distrued it is), Til it toward þe neuen cam. A castel þei seie fer hem fram: To þe gate þai riden, iwis. Of þe porter Heraud gan craue, ‘Tel me now, so god þe saue, Was þis castel is? Forhel it nou?t, we bedeþ þe: Kni?tes we beþ of fer contre, Ase god ?eue vs blis. 69 Þis in we beddeþ par cherite, For godes loue in trinite, Þat is lord [so] fre. To-morwe anon so it is day We scholle wenden in our way Towardes our contre.’ Þe porter answerde anon ri?t, ‘Of þis lord i ne can telle no-wi?t, Ne in what contre a be. Ac a leuedi her-in is Ful of del and sorwe, y-wis: Wel sore wepeþ ?he 70 For hire lord þat ?he haþ lore: Ioie ne worþ hire neuer þer-fore For non menstralcie.’ Þe porter in anon gan wende, And tolde tale ord and ende To Amis is leuedy: ‘Madame, her beþ come twei kni?te: Noble men hii be in fi?te. Þai wolde her soiurny Al þis ni?t, for soþ to say, To-morwe wenden in her way: Þarof y nou?t ne lye.’ 71 Þe leuedi seide, ‘let hym in: Þai scholle be serued wel afyn, Be þe grace of god almi?te.’ Þe porter wente a?en anon, & to þe gate he gan gon, & let hem in ful ri?te. Þe kni?tes were kende kore: Whan þai come to halle dore, Adoun þai gonne li?te. Men toke here swerdes, scheld, & spere, Here stedes, and here oþer gere: Ful wel men gan hem di?te. 72 Þe leuedi faire grete hem anon: To vnarme hem hire-selue is gon Wiþ a wel gode chere. Here mete was redi wiþ-outen let: Anon hii were adoun y-set To þe sopere. Heraud askede hire, y-wis, ‘Dame, what þe lordes nam is Fayn ich wolde hire.’ ‘Of þe Montayne he het Amis: Wiþinne Almayne no swich þer nis, Me leue frendes dere. 73 A stiward was wiþ þemperour (To al Almayne he was treitour), Sire Berard of Paui: Me lordes swike euer was he; Þour? him in al þis sorwe we be. For þe loue of sire Gij, Þat me lord louede wel, & sokoured him in is castel, We beþ in gret vileinie. For þe dukes deþ Otoun, Þat was a treitour feloun, He vs gan beli?e, 74 And made vs fle out of þat londe, & in þis contre we beþ astonde, Þat wonder is of si?t: Mechel Arderne cleped it is. A fairy kni?t herin is Þat is of meche mi?t: Wiþ him ones fau?t me lord, & ?af him dentes wiþ is sword Vpon is helm bri?t. Wepne mai him dere non: He is so hard to hewe vpon Ase marbel, y þe pli?t. 75 On a dai me lord honted a best, & drof it out of þe forest Wiþ-inne is merkes stake. Siþþe herde ich of him namore: Þarfore me of-dredeþ sore Þe kni?t him haue take.’ ‘Allas,’ queþ Heraud, ‘is it Amis, Þerl of Montaine of gret pris?’ Gret sorwe he gan make. ‘O,’ a seide, ‘sire Reinbroun, Wel a louede þe fader Gioun: We mote him helpe for is sake.’ 76 Reinbroun seide, ase he was hende, ‘Tomorwe ich wile þerder wende To seche sire Amis.’ ‘Me swete frend,’ queþ þe leuedi, ‘Be þow nou?t to foul-hardi; For gret perel it is.’ Amorwe Reinbroun aros erly, And armede him ful hastely, For to winne pris. A gode stede he bestrod, & forþ a wente wiþ-oute abod To þe forest, ywis. 77 Heraud wiþ him go wolde, Ac he seide þat he ne scholde For non skines nede, & he dradde of him strangliche, & betau?te him god in heuen riche, & in is wey a ?ede. Heraud blefte, & he gan gon: Þe merkes stake a pased anon, Þat was wel vnrede. Al þe dai a tok þe pas, Til it noun apased was, Ridand vpon is stede. 78 An hille he se? before him þere: Gates þeron maked were. Forþ ri?t he rod in. Þe gate a?en anon was spered: Þo was Reinbroun sore afered, & faste blessede him. Nou?t he ne se? boute þesternesse. Half a mile a rod, ywisse: Þe wai was þerk and dim. He rod ase faste ase a mi?te: Þanne he se? more li?te Be a water is brim. 79 To þe water he com sone þas: A riuer be a launde þer was; Þar he gan to li?te. Faire hit was y-growe wiþ gras: A fairer place neuer nas Þat he se? wiþ si?te. On þat place was a paleis on: Swich ne se? he neuer non, Ne of so meche mi?te. Þe walles were of cristal, Þe heling was of fin ruwal Þat schon swiþe bri?te. 80 Þe reftes al cipres be, Þat swote smal casten he Ouer al aboute. Þe resins wer of fin coral, To-gedre iuned wiþ metal Wiþ-inne and ek wiþ-oute. On þe front stod a charbokel ston: Ouer al þe contre it schon, Wiþ-outen eni doute. Postes and laces þat þer were Of iaspe gentil þat was dere, Al of one soute. 81 Þe paleis was beloken al Aboute wiþ a marbel wal Of noble entaile. Vpon eueriche kernal Was ful of speres & of springal, And stoutliche enbataile. Wiþoute þe gate stod a tre Wiþ foules of mani kines gle Singande, wiþ-oute faile. Þe water was so sterne & grim, Mi?te no man come þerin, Boute he hadde schip to saile. 82 Reinbroun dorste nou?t pasy: Wiþ is spere a gan it prouy, How dep hit was beside. He þou?te on is fader fot hot: Þe stede in þe side a smot, & in he gan to ride. Ouer is helm þe water is gon: He nolde haue be þer for ei?te non; Swich aunter him gan betide. Er he vp of þe water ferde, A fond it was þretti mete ?erde: So dep he gan doun glide. 83 Þanne he þou?te on Iesu Crist: His hors was wel swiþe trist, & quikliche swam to londe: His fet fastnede on þe grounde. Reinbroun was glad in þat stounde, And þankede gode[s] sonde. In-to þe pales he him dede: He [be]helde þe est[r]es of þat stede; For no man a nolde wonde. Ac wimman ne man fand he non þere Þat wiþ him speke or confort bere Naiþer sitte ne stonde. 84 And þar-of war a is. Into a chaumber a goþ, y-wis: A knight a se? al-one. A grette him wiþ wordes fre, & seide, ‘sire, god wiþ þe be, Þat sit an he? in trone. Sire,’ a sede, ‘tel þow me ?if þis pales þin owen be: Ich bidde þe a bone. &, ?if þow ert her in prisoun di?t, Tel hit me, so wel þow mi?t: To me now make þe mone.’ 85 Amis answerde to Reinbroun, ‘In Almayne ich was a baroun, And now icham for-lore. Ich was driue out wiþ a feloun, And now y lye her in prisoun: Allas þat ich was bore! Of þis paleis inam no lord. Ich telle þe a soþe word Wiþoute oþ iswore: Hit is a kni?tes of fayri, And al þis forest her-by, A sterne man y-kore. 86 Þis paleys is of swiche mi?t, Her schel no man elde, apli?t, Be he her neuer so longe. Þei he wer her a þosand ?er, In is heued schel hore non her, Ne non elde fonge.’ Reinbroun seide, ‘ert þow Amis, Þerl of Montayne of gret pris? Þow singest a reuly songe. Now ichaue fonde þe, Þow schelt wende now wiþ me Out of þe paines stronge.’ 87 Amis seide, ‘spek nou?t so: Of þe me wondreþ, so mot y go, Þat þow ert hider y-come. Siþe þis world ferst began, In þis paleis ne com noman, Boute ?if a wer i-nome, Boute ?if þe lord him hider ladde, Oþer of him sum leue hadde: Nis non so hardi gome. How mi?test þow lede me, Whan þow mi?t nou?t saue þe? Ich telle þe at þe frome.’ 88 Reinbroun seide, ‘drede nou?t þe; Þar-fore schel hit nou?t lete be. Go we anon ri?t. ?if eni man so hardi were Þat vs wolde at-helde here, His deþ wer y-di?t: Swich a strok ich him ?eue wolde, Þat is heued lese a scholde, Be grace of god almi?t. Þei he wer te bataile boun Ase sterne alse eni lyoun, Wiþ him ich wile fi?t.’ 89 Amis seide, ‘let now be: Swiche stringþe mai nou?t helpe þe A?enes sire Gayere; For noþing ne schel him dere Wiþ no wepne þat man may bere, Naiþer stel ne yre; Ac, ?if þow wilt ouercome him, Þat ilche swerd to þe nym Þat hangeþ a þe pylere.’ Reinbroun braide it out anon ri?t: Þe chaumber was al ful of li?t Þat schon swiþe clere. 90 To þerl Amis anon a wond, & tok him vp be þe hond: No leng hii nolde abide. Out of þe paleys boþe hii ?ede, And lopen on Reinbroun is stede, And forþ þai gonne ride. Nou?t fer þannes beþ hii gon, Þai be-held a?en anon Vpon here ri?t side: Comande hii se?e ride a kni?t Upon a stede gode and li?t, Prikande wiþ pride. 91 Swift ase swalwe he com ride: ‘Kni?tes,’ a seide, ‘?e scholle abide, No forþer þat ?e ne wende. In me paleys þow hast y-be, And me prisoun ledest wiþ þe: Þow dost a dede vn-hende. Her ?e sholle bleue bo In me prisoun for euer-mo Into þe worldes ende, Or þow schelt, Reinbroun, þin hed forgo. Kep for me: icham þe fo; Bataile y wile þe sende.’ 92 Þerl Amys þer ali?te: Arome he drou? him anon ri?te, And Reinbroun Gayer gan smite. Gret strokes hii smite betwene, Þat adoun hii fellen bene: Aiþer sparede oþer lite. Siþe þai drowe brondes on grounde, & hewe to-gedre wiþ grimly wounde Wiþ swerdes þat wolde bite. ?e herde neuer a stringe[r] fi?t. Reinbroun stirede him as gode kni?t: Hit was him nou?t to wite. 93 He þou?te on is fader anon ri?t: Ase fresch a was to fi?t Ase grehonde to hare. Betwene hem twie was gret fi?t: Aiþer smot oþer in helmes bri?t, And delde dentes sare. Þai hewe helm and scheldes bo: Gret fi?t was betwene hem to; Swich herde ?e neuer are. Reinbroun made him to blede, And felde him doun of is stede: Þanne was he out of care. 94 Reinbroun be þe nose him tok, And drou? to him, & faste him schok: Þat greuede him ful sore. His heued benome him he hadde Ner it þat he merci gradde, & seide, ‘sire R[e]inbroun, þin ore, For þe fader loue Gii, Þe beste kni?t, sikerly, Þat euer was y-bore. Wiþ þat þow haue merci on me, Al me prisouns diliured be, And hennes for euermore.’ 95 R[e]inbroun seide, ‘so y schel: In þat forward y graunte wel Þat þow aliue go, So þe prisouns diliured be; Þar-to þe treuþe pli?te me Betwene vs-selue to.’ R[e]inbroun glad & bliþe is: He hadde diliured sire Amis, Þre hondred kni?tes & mo. Into þe castel wenten hii, Þar was Heraud & þe leuedy Ful of sorwe and wo. 96 Þai wer welcomed wiþ fair gle. Whan þe leuedi hire lord gan se, ?he made meche blis, & Heraud, forsoþe, dede also, And herede god almi?ti þo, And Amis he gan kisse. Heraud tolde him al is treye, How he hadde in prisoun leye, For-soþe wiþ-outen misse, Fo[r] me lordes loue Reynbroun, What sorwe he hadde in prisoun, Honger, and þesternesse. 97 ‘Þis is Reinbroun, Gii is sone, Þat haþ set þe out of prisone, And [brou?t] þe out of þe care.’ Al is lif a tolde him þo, How Gij was out of londe y-go, And how hit was y-fare. Among hem gret ioie þer is: In þe castel was meche blis Among alle þare. Euerich of hem oþer gan kisse, And made meche ioie & blisse: For blisse þai wepe ful sare. 98 Wiþ þat þer com a kni?t riding: To þerl Amis a brou?te tiding Fro þat emperur, Þat þe duk Berard ded is: A palmer slou? him, y-wis, Wiþ wel mechel onour. Þemperur hadde sent is sonde A scholde come, and [haue] is londe, Boþe toune and tour; & þat þerl Terry and he Were skyred and maked fre Þour? þe conquerur. 99 Sire Amis wiþ is meyne Wente hom to is contre To þat emperour: A ?af him is londes fre, Boþe castel and cite, Wiþ wel meche onour. Glad of him was þemperur fre: Euer a was to him priue Boþe in halle and bour. And also was þerl Terry, Þat was þerles sone Aubry, A man of gret fauour. 100 Heraud & Reinbroun tok leue þo Into Ingelonde te go: Þanne was þe leuedi in care. Mani iurne þai ride þo Þour? Spayne & þour? londes mo: Into Bourgoyne þai come ware; Þe contre was strued doun ri?t. Heraud askede at a kni?t How hit was y-fare. He seide, ‘þe duk of Marce y-told, Þat is a stout kni?t and bold, Vs haþ y-brou?t in care. 101 Vpon our erl werreþ he: He naþ leued boute þis cite, Þat he naþ y-nome. Ac þis castel is gode engyn: Noblech a wereþ him þer-in Also a dou?ti gome. Wiþ him he haþ a noble kni?t, His souder, siker apli?t, Þat to him is y-come. ?ong a is, so þenkeþ me, Nou?t twenti winter old nis he, Ich telle þe at þe frome. 102 In þis launde her-before An hondred haþ her lif y-lore, Whan he se? hem ride. Her forþ ne schel pase no kni?t, ?if he haþ brenye or stede li?t, Þat he ne schel abide, And for-lese þer þat on, Oþer is heued ri?t anon Be þe wode side. ?if ?e be þat launde gon, Ich telle ?ow be sein Ion, Swich aunture ?ow schel betide.’ 103 ‘O, god be þanked,’ queþ Reinbroun, ‘Ichaue founde me compaynoun, Me felle wiþ to fi?te. ?if he wile haue oure þing, Y schel him teche, wiþ-outen lesing, Þat he doþ vnri?te.’ Nou?t fer þanne ne beþ þai gon, Þai be-helde a?en anon: Hii si?e his armes bri?te Vpon a stede whit so flour; His armes wer of rede kolour, A semede of meche mi?te. 104 ‘Sire Heraud,’ seide Reinbroun, ‘Now y se þat bolde baroun Þat is so stout a fere. Wiþ vs to fi?te he makeþ him ?are: Wiþ him to iusten ich wile fare Emforþ me powere. Ich him asaile, ?if þow wilt so.’ Heraud seide, ‘so þow schelt do, Me leue sone dere.’ Swiþe þeder rod Reinbroun, & he in þe launde com adoun Vpon is deistrere. 105 Aiþer was prout & mody: No word þai speke, sikerly, To-gedres þai gonne driue. Aiþer hitte oþer in þe scheld, Þat boþe hii fellen in þe feld Of here hors beliue. Siþe þai drowe brondes of stel, And hewe togedre hard & wel, And delde dentes riue, & laiden on wiþ swerdes clere: Helm and scheld, þat stronge were, Þai gonne hem al to-schliue. 106 Heraud beheld longe þat fi?t: For Reinbroun a bad te god almi?t Þat he non harm ne fonge. To him-selue a seide þare Swich fi?t ne se? he neuer are Of dentes þat were stronge. ‘Sire kni?t,’ seide Reinbroun, ‘Vnderstand to me resoun, So god þe saule fonge, Ac neuer ne fond ich a kni?t Þat me strokes dri?e mi?t Haluendel so longe. 107 What is þe name? whar wer þe bore? Ich þe praie, tel me fore, For loue of oure dri?te, &, ?if þow wost ?elde þe, Ich schel þe lede to me contre. Me treuþe i schel þe pli?te: Y schel þe ?eue castel & cite, Bourwes, & tounes, & riche fe, And mani a dou?ti kni?te; For þow ert of gret power: In al þis world þer nis þe per Þat man finde mi?te. 108 ‘Sire kni?t,’ þanne answerde he, ‘Y nel nou?t, be him þat made me, Telle þe me name. Þour? þe sarmoun scheltow nou?t wite Whar y was boren ne gete An erneste ne a game: Erst y schel þe sle, verament. Sire, let be þe prechement: Hit is þe meche schame; Ac neuer kni?t i ne fond So wel worchande wiþ dent of brond Þat ich fau?t wiþ y-same. 109 Ac y ne sei nou?t for þam: Þin heued y schel smite þe fram, For-soþe, wiþ-oute more. Þat olde man þat ich y-se (Y ne wot ?if he þe fader be, Or þow ert wiþ him at lore), Lite a louede [þe], siker þow be, Whan a sente þe to me, He wiþ þe berde hore. Whan ichaue þin hed of-take, Be þe berd y schel him schake, Þat him schel smerte sore. 110 So y schel him þer-bi ploke, Þat al is teþ schel roke Þat sitteþ in is heued.’ &, þo Reinbroun herde þis, Þat Heraud dispised is, His swerd to him a weued: A strok a smot is helm vpon, Þat a quarter gan doun gon; Hit was half to-cleued. Wiþ þat strok a stente adoun al, & to þe erþe a is y-fal: His lif ne? he hadde leued. 111 ‘O frend,’ a seide, ‘ich bidde þe lete; For it is meche foly to þrete Eni man aliue.’ & he ascorn bad him lete, And a sterte vpon is fete Hasteliche and bliue. Haslak smot Reinbroun anon, Þat to þe bokel þe schel[d] chon: Ne? a gan doun driue. Strong and gode hii wer boþe: Eiþer kedde þat hii wer wroþe To bringe oþer of liue. 112 Betwene hem strong fi?t þer is: Swich ne herde [?e] neuer, iwis, Siþe þat ?e wer bore. So mi?te nou?t longe be: Þat [on] moste þat oþer sle Of þe kni?tes kende i-core. Heraud be-held þat bataile, How aiþer gan oþer asaile: Wo was him þer-fore. A gret harm him þou?te it were ?if aiþer slou? oþer þere: For hem a wep wel sore. 113 Wiþ þat amonges hem com he, And seide, ‘kni?t, for godes pite, Herkne to me a stounde. Let now ben al ?our fi?t, And a?ild þe to þis kni?t Þat þou hast her y-founde. For he is man of gret power: In al þis world þer nis is per, Ne of so meche mounde. In is merci, y rede, þow [þe] do, Er þan be mad betwene ?ow to Eni mo harde wounde.’ 114 He answerde wiþ-oute more, ‘Say me ferst, þow faimel hore, Also god þe spede, Why me stringþe is for-lore: Siþþe þe time þat ich was bore Y nas in swiche a drede. ?if þow ert of fendes come, For whi þis drede me haue nome, Ich wolde þat þow me sede. In gode[s] name ich coniure þe Þat þow þe soþe telle me, And be al is ferede.’ 115 Heraud seide, ‘þer-of be stille: Þat telle þe [nis] me wille For noman aliue. Erst þow schelt telle me Wheþen þow ert, & what thow be, Also mote y þriue. Þanne y schel telle þe ri?t Boþe of me and of þis kni?t Þat ?if[þ] þe dentes riue. Þin hauberk is al to-si?e, And þe face wiþ blod bewri?e Of woundes mo þan fiue.’ 116 He answerde, ‘þow seist wel. Boute for drede, be sein Mi?el, Y nolde ben aknowe, Ac for ich wolde wite an haste Whi ich was so sore agaste Now in a lite þrowe. In Ingelonde ich was bore, So were min eldren me before Boþe he? and lowe. Heraud me fader het, y-wis: Of Walingforde lord a is, And al þe contre is owe. 117 Out of londe þan wente he To seche Gi is sone þe fre, Þat marchauns stele away. To þerl of Winchester y was sent: Þar ich was loked, veraiment, Boþe ni?tes and day. Whan ich was woxe of meche pris, Dou?ti, and swiþe strong, y-wis, Me felawes gonne say Þat y nas of dedes nou?t, For þat y me fader [ne] sou?t In vnkouþe contray. 118 To Walingforde y gan gon, Me fader is armes þer y fond anon, His hauberk and is stede, His scheld, and is helm bri?t, And is swerd gode and li?t, Þat he was woned to lede. Me selue y dobbed me kni?t þare: Man ne tolde ich it neuer are, Also god me spede. Out of þat londe ich wente þo To seche me fader [in] wer & wo In mani an vnkouþ þede. 119 Of werre ne herde y neuer speke, Þat y ne com þer me fader to seke: Þus to þis lord y cam. Þe duk of Marce haþ strued him, Boute þis castel is gode engyn. Þe lord þat y wiþ am Ne? he hadde is lond for-lore (Swiþe wo was him þar-fore), And mani a dou?ti man. Boute þretti hors he nadde þo: Now he haþ þre hondred & mo Þat ich in bataile wan.’ 120 Heraud herde þis wordes alle: Byter teres he let doun falle, And seide, ‘what is the name?’ ‘Haslak,’ a seide, ‘þow schelt me calle. Heraud het me fader in halle, & Cristiane het me dame. Now þow wost whar ich was bore, And what ich hatte wiþ-oute more An erneste and agame: To forward þow schelt telle me Whi ich was afered of þe Þat we made er y-same.’ 121 Heraud beheld þe ?onge kni?t, Ac o word speke he ne mi?t For meche ioie and blisse. ‘Heraud is me name, apli?t, And þow Haslak y se wiþ si?t, Me sone, wiþ-oute misse. Þis is þe lord, sire Reinbroun: Ichaue had for him in prisoun Honger and þesternesse. Þe mi?t him se: a stant þe by. ?ild him þe swerd in is merci, And pray him þat he þe kisse.’ 122 Þo Haslak wiste sikerly Hit was is fader þat stod him by, And is lord Reinbroun, Swiþe loude he gan to crie, ‘Fader, for loue of oure leuedye, ?em me þe benesoun.’ Ofte he knewelede to þe grounde, And cride him merci in þat stounde Wiþ gode deuocioun. ‘In þe merci y do me ri?t, And euermore to ben þe kni?t Boþe in feld and toun.’ 123 Þo Reinbroun wiste þis, Þat he Heraud is sone is, Up he gan him take. Leueliche a kiste him þo, Sire Heraud, for-soþ, dede also: Meche blisse þai gonne make. Haslak ladde hem faire and wel Hom til is lordes castel, And tolde, wiþ-oute sake, Þat he hadde is fader brou?t Þat he hadde wide y-sou?t Wiþ meche wer and wrake, 124 ‘And me lord, sire Reinbroun, Ase sterne ase eni lyoun At euery skenes nede, Þat euer to bataile was boun.’ Glad was þanne þerl Myloun, And ?af hem riche mede Þe kni?tes of seluer & of golde, Ase meche as he take wolde, Bri?t armur and stede. So þai wente sone anon For to wreke hem of here fon, ?if god hem wolde spede. 125 Fiue dawes before þe Mi?el-mas Þai armede hem more & las A?en here fon to fi?te. Out of þe castel þai gonne pas: Þe duk hii fonden in þe plas Wiþ mani helmes bri?te. Þar mi?te men se scheftes schake, Þar men mi?te se crounes crake Of mani an hardy kni?te. Heraud, Haslak, and Reinbroun— Al þat hii smite ?ede adoun Of þai hii mete mi?te. 126 Þe duk of Marce se? þat tide His folk was slawe be ech aside, & in þe feld alto-dreued. He prikede is stede wiþ meche pride: A?enes þerl he gan ride, And smot him on þe heued. Almest a felde þerl adoun: Heraud com wiþ is fauchoun, His body ato he cleued. Þanne Haslak and Reinbroun Þerl is folk þai felde adoun: Noþing þai ne leued. 127 Þis se? al þe barnage: For to do þerl omage, Merci þai gonne crie. Kni?tes, squier, and page Þai toke þer in-to ostage Of þe duk is partye. Þus þai stablede þe lond wiþ fi?t, & þerafter anon ri?t Þai toke leue an hi?e. In-te Ingelonde þai gonne saile. [A Londres sont tut dreit ale, Ou le rei Athelstan ont troue. Le rei encontre eus est ale, Od li le meulz de la cite. Mult duement les ad honure, E del suen assez done. A Rainbrun doune sun conte, E si lui acrest mult sun fie. Treis iours i ont soiurne, Al quart ont pris lur congie, A Warewik uunt, la bone cite: Cil del pais sunt mult le. Rainbrun prent de ses hommes feute: Mult par est entre eus ame. Heraud sen ua a Walingeford, A son chastel bon e fort. Desore i uodra soiurner Od sa femme, bone mulier, Kar mult ad son cors trauaille En plusurs lius por sa leaute. De ceste estorie uoil fin faire: Plus nen uoil desore traire. Bel ensaumple i peut em prendre Qui bien la siet e ueut entendre De pruesce amer, leaute tenir, De tuz biens faire e mal gerpir, Orguil, richesces auer en despit: De Guion nus aprent le escrit Ceo est la summe de la ualur, Ke tut guerpi pur sun creatur. E cil qui en la sainte trinite Vn deu est par sa pite Nus doint en terre si servir, Ke ali en glorie puissums venir. Amen.]
